Ratings.comment: Professor Cabanes is by far my favorite professor that I have had so far. He is more than willing to hear other views or respond to any questions. His exams are a large part of the grade but he makes sure you are prepared for them. The other assignments were actually enjoyable because it was either a movie or book. Would definitely recommend.

I enjoyed Mr. Cabanes' class a ton. The lectures were interesting. Homework consisted of watching movies and reading a few books so it wasn't difficult. The class is exam-heavy but the only really difficult ones are the Midterm and the Final, the movie exams aren't very difficult and are very fun to do. I would highly recommend this class!

Cabanes is incredibly kind and the lectures were always interesting as he is very knowledgeable about war. The grader for the course is a little tough and there are only 3 quizzes on movies, a midterm, final, & book essay which meant the weight of things was high. Easy review sessions for midterm and final w TONS of extra credit. Take this class!

Clearly knowledgeable about the material and makes the lectures very interesting. Read several short books and watched films outside of class. Grading based on two exams and a paper along with pop quizzes based on the readings. Fairly easy class and a great professor

Heavy course material but done in a way that is super interesting and really engaging. Professor Cabanes is a great professor, he's clear about themes in the class and emphasizes important concepts over intricate details, which is very refreshing for a history course. It's the first history course I've genuinely enjoyed in while.

The class is extremely interesting to the point I wished the lectures were longer. There is a clear grading criteria and the exams are easy. You have to take detailed notes and pay attention if you want to pass. Not going to lecture and sitting on your phone or computer will dramatically affect your grade. There are pop quizzes on readings.

Bruno was a great professor with detailed notes. His lectures were heavy and detailed, but organized and interesting. He and the TA made sure you were prepared for the exams and finals. Very interesting course.
Pop quizzes, one paper, midterm, final. The lectures are chock-full of information and dry if you aren't that into history. But no doubt you will learn a ton.

History minor, expected an easy A, but you will only get an A if you work reasonably hard. This was his first class taught at OSU, so the material is being pared down a lot, but originally it was a LOT of reading (60 pgsnight).FANTASTIC professor, cool French accent, great focus on EXPERIENCE of war (not military tactics). Interesting lectures!
Professor Esposito was an amazing lecturer and person, very accommodating for all circumstances and class work was straightforward!

Well-organized online class consisting of weekly discussion posts and then a final paper. Dr. Esposito's lectures as well as the readings are informative and interesting. Guidelines are clear and you can choose from multiple essay topics for the final essay.

I loved taking this class this semester. I dropped Spanish and needed another to fill its spot and I'm SO glad that I did. Only graded on 7 assignments which are all discussion boards, final essay topic and guidelines given well in advance, and overall just an interesting class. If you're into anthropology like myself I think you'll enjoy it!
I took Professor Tuxberry-Gleissner's SLAVIC 3320 class as a GENED. It was easy and pretty interesting. I would recommend if you are interested in Eastern European culture, if not you WILL be bored.

I really did not enjoy taking this class. He never put any grades in and rambled on and on during lectures. He is very caring and appreciated whenever any students went to office hours or talked to him, but only when it was convenient for him. Really unclear what he wanted from essay assignments and the organization of the Carmen page was bad.

Professor Rivers was extremely interesting to listen to and learn from. Yes his lectures did ramble on, but if you paid attention and took notes the papers and exams were easy. My best advice is to go to his office hours. His communication through email is rough at best, but if you go to office hours he will explain everything.

Six papers overall, two outside of class FOUR in two separate tests (+long discussions). He will not grade anything and even if he reads your email he will not respond to it, even if he TOLD YOU TO. Lectures are rambling and if he is on topic it's because he's reading directly from the slide or his notes.

Dr Rivers is extremely knowledgeable in his field and I learned a ton in this class. He is very willing to work with students and even met on weekends to accommodate us. However, he is so inaccessible by email and will only respond on his time. His lectures are a bit scattered and often go off topic. Great guy, super smart, but not the best prof

He is kind but, has awful communication. We have finished classes for the year and I have no grades. Emailed him 4 times this week (asked in class several times) for grades, no response. Lectures go off topic every two seconds. Way too much content in carmen (he literally couldn't upload anymore items). Expects entirely too much in assignments.

I took 3620 over the summer online. It was Dr. Rivers' first time teaching online and he did really well. Course content was very interesting and he is very clearly passionate and educated on the subject matter. Two main essays that he was happy to go over and help, he was incredible.

I feel really bad giving him the score I did because he genuinely cares so much about what he teaches and I really did learn a lot. Here is the main issue: his communication is abysmal. I am NOT exaggerating when I tell you that I did not receive a single grade until the DAY grades were due and he did not respond to a SINGLE e-mail of mine.
Glad, I have him as my history professor. I learned a lot of stuff during lectures and I appreciate to give me an opportunity to complete all my assignment before end of semester.

Professor Rivers is a very knowledgeable and gives interesting lectures. I have taken two classes with him and overall the experience is very positive. He tries to cover history from a vast range of group but focuses a lot on lgbtq+ and Lesbian history. The class focuses a lot on primary sources from activist or queer people from these periods.

Dr. Rivers is a really great person, but a very poor professor. He does not lecture clearly, and ends up going off on tangents frequently. I do not feel that I learned anything, his papers and tests are unclear, and I did not feel prepared for any of it based on his lectures. He takes far too long to give feedback which is frustrating.

Rivers, even if he was hard to contact at times, is a great guy. It is obvious not only that he is interested in the material, but also that he cares a lot about the mental health and learning of his students. If you can put up with his inconsistency on emails, his class is 100 percent worth it. A plus is that the information is also interesting.

It's clear that Prof Rivers is very smart but he is probably the worst professor I've ever had. Never responded to anyone's emails, vague instructions for papers and exams,only gave us grades for the midterm(six weeks late and over email, still no grades in canvas at all) and has yet to grade any papers or the final. extremely disorganized

Prof Rivers did not respond to a single email I sent him the entire semester. He disappeared from class for weeks then posted lectures he recorded in the summer. Why it took him weeks to post pre-recorded lectures, I do not know. It is currently April 3, 2021 and this class is a SP21 and I have no grade in the class. He does not communicate at all.

He literally disappeared for my History class. We had maybe 5 assignments and then a Midterm (6 pages, single spaced...) and then a final paper (4 pages, single spaced). We had to contact the History Department chair to literally take over the class. He never responded to emails or anything: would not recommend.

The subject matter is interesting but the experience isn't worth it. He seems sweet but doesn't respond to emails, offer office hours regularly, and disappears for weeks. All assignments require a ridiculous amount of writing (ex. 2+ pages SINGLE SPACED/answer for papers). This class has brought me so much stress in an already stressful semester...

He literally doesn't respond to emails. Had to have the head of the history department step in for our class because he stopped posting assignments for 3 weeks. Midterm was brutal (so much work), and gave us even more work for the final before being told by others that it's a bad idea. When he came back after 3 weeks, he uploaded 68 files at once.

This class stressed me out so much during the pandemic! He would post PDFs on Carmen once a month and never answered emails. For weeks at a time he would never post anything on Canvas or communicate with anybody, he just went MIA.

Professor Rivers seems like a good guy, he just totally botched this semester. I understand it is his first time doing a class online, but he was missing in action for like 2 weeks. Not even exaggerating. His class was asynchronous and he only posted like 4 lectures. The midterm was 3 questions with one 2+ page paper each, single-spaced. Yikes.

Online class- waited 40 mins before class telling students that we are expected to do everything ourselves. Grades discussions late and post discussions late. I really like his lectures but this semester felt like a hot mess. I am not impressed with him.

Professor Rivers is an amazing lecturer! His lectures are heavy with information, so you really need to attend to get the information. There are assigned readings every week (to be discussed in recitation), but it's not too much. He provides the exam questions 2 weeks prior so that you can prepare your essay response. 10/10 recommend!

Nice professor, but her grading criteria are extraordinary, her discussion posts don't make any sense and then when you try to give some form of answer, she tells you to go to the Writing Center. if the assignment does not make any sense and all the students are confused about it, they might as well just do book report assignments then.

Engaging, passionate, and friendly professor. Post-WWII European History is a complicated and fascinating area that I knew nothing about! Grading is a little strange, she isn't particularly harsh but rarely gives grades above 95 and almost never above 98. There's a midterm and final paper, and a bunch of reflection papers (6 required, 10 assigned)

This class was alright I guess. The grading criteria were not clear at all, and you get docked points for the stupidest things. Also, the lectures are so boring, I have taken European History classes multiple times, and this is the worst one.

Despite my loathing of a majority of the material, I genuinely enjoyed this class and felt that I had actually learned a lot by the end of the semester. Dr. Dragostinova is very smart and likes the material she is teaching, which made the class better overall. To pass, all you should really have to do is watch the lectures and take notes!
Don't take this class for an easy elective. Nit-picky grader over small stuff and requires a lot more effort than a 3 credit elective should in my opinion.

She's a great professor. One map quiz, five response papers, a book review, midterm and final research project. The response papers, book review, and quiz are easy but the midterm was difficult (essay) and she looks for specific answers on the prompts. Make sure you understand what she is looking for in the papers. A LOT of reading, but a fun class

Professor Dragostinova was always energetic and excited to teach. As long as you fill out the outlines for every class you dont need to do the readings as the tests are based on the lecture material. The weekly discussion posts were a big part of the grade, but she does give extra credit opportunities and points for attendance which helps.

Professor Dragostinova is an amazing professor for modern european history. If I had to take another class with her I would. She genuinely cares about the material & loves teaching it & I actually was excited to go to class everyday. She's Bulgarian & has a slight accent but its clear & you know what she is saying at all times and isnt a problem.

Goldish is very knowledgeable and funny but goes on tangents which can be boring, especially in a class where no electronics are allowed. He grades fairly, but if you're not interested in the Salem Witch Trials the coursework can get repetitive.

I found this class pretty easy. As long as you can watch a movie and do a (lowkey pretty long) reading every week, you're solid. His lectures are extremely boring but a of of people just left after taking the weekly quiz (which were easy if you did the hw.) The final test was online and the final paper was pretty fun to write.

Pretty easy GE but expect to read 60-90 pages a week. if you are not willing to read and manage the homework effectively, don't take this class. There is a quiz every week then long lecture afterwards. Paper was super easy, but he graded really strict on the final. He's pretty nice and responds quickly.

You can pour tons of time into taking notes and preparing for one class, but then there's no quiz on it. But the next class where you maybe didn't have time to annotate as much or have to miss for a UNIVERSITY SANCTIONED EVENT you best believe there will be a quiz. He drops two quizzes, but heaven forbid you're involved, there won't be an exception

The professor is so old-fashioned. No lecture material, he did not write anything on the board. It was like listening to a podcast but getting graded on it. The quizzes were on details from the long readings, so you cannot just skim them. Horrible experience. We live in 2023. Learn how to adapt to the times or do not teach.

Professor Goldish is one of a kind!!! His extensive knowledge on history and ability to teach it through a variety of perspectives is really interesting. He is super funny, so staying awake in class is never an issue. There is a movie and reading assignment every week that you get quizzed on, but they are very simple with no tricks :)

Professor Goldish does a wonderful job of making sure the students have to be involved in both the reading and the class by actively engaging in both conversation and the use of pop quizzes. Do not take this class if you are not willing to read outside of class and take decent notes within class. He is also fairly anti-technology, bring paper/pen.

There's a lot of reading, pop quizzes, no lecture slides, and no technology allowed in class w/o an exemption so if that's not your style this course isn't for you. I found the subject matter super interesting and unique and enjoyed Dr. Goldish, he is knowledgeable and passionate about his class. I would recommend to anyone who enjoys niche history

Professor Goldish laid out his expectations clearly in class and in the syllabus and wasn't lying! This is a high level history course, so don't expect to go in and learn spells and watch Hocus Pocus. If you are one that likes PowerPoints to guide your notes, you will not enjoy his lectures. Read his syllabus carefully as it lays out everything.

An average class. Dont expect anything like slides or key topics. If you do the readings, youll be fine, but make sure you take good notes in class. Lectures are not engaging. Not too difficult, just not too interesting either.

This is a HISTORY class, NOT broomsticks and spells. You WILL learn ways people classify religion, science, and technology as magic. The professor expects college level work and does ask you to prepare your own notes. He will not spell out the material for you. Class is based on assigned readings and discussions as well as easy quizzes.

Professor Goldish is awesome! Be prepared for class and show up and it will be rewarding! I am not a history major and took this as a fun history credit with no prior knowledge and was able to succeed in this course. Be sure to actually read the syllabus and understand how the course works before committing to it! Totally recommend for all majors.

Professor Goldish was interesting. He definitely seemed extremely knowledgeable in the subject, but either wanted to show off his intellect or thought he was teaching a higher level class. This course felt like it was incorrectly marked as a GE, but fits a high level history course. Lots of reading and lectures that didn't really apply to the text

Professor Goldish is probably the smartest person I have ever met, and his intellect is comparable to some of the great thinkers of the Scientific Revolution that we learned about in his class. The course was lecture and reading heavy, but his lectures were engaging and informative and I enjoyed every one. The class isn't for the faint of mind.
Prof Goldish was a really nice guy and had very few assignments that weren't that bad. The lectures were a bit boring sometimes when he would go on tangents.

Vehemently excluded Black jewish people from the course content and was argumentative about Black and brown Jewish peoples importance in the community. Centered the entire class around the contributions of white rabbinates, while entirely excluding Black and brown qaraites.

This class was a hybrid class (only meets 1x per week) so there is a decent amount of work / reading that you must do outside of class, but that's just what comes with a hybrid class. Prof. Goldish was incredibly knowledgeable regarding just about everything you could think of and as long as you read, you'll do just fine in the class.

I took his history of apocalypticism class and really enjoyed it. This class isn't for everyone. It was a 3 hr lecture with really heavy reading. I found professor goldish to be hilarious & extremely knowledgeable. This isn't an easy A but you learn a lot and it will change your perspective on a lot of different world issues. 10/10 would recommend.

Other than the fact that the class was a three hour lecture, I quite enjoyed my time in Professor Goldish's class. The man held my interest for more than half of each lecture, which was much more than I expected for a freshman history class that I was only taking to meet the requirement.

I am astounded every week at just how much this guy knows and loves to learn. He said last week he went several years reading Newton's manuscripts for 5 hours every day. He's written movies and books. Theres a lot of reading and the lectures get boring, but if you want to learn from an actual genius and a successful person, take a class with him.
Great.  Expert.  Knowledgeable.  Caring.  Folksy comments; all good.  Don't try to correct him.  He knows a lot of good things.
Excellent.  Creative.  Gives good feedback.  Interesting lectures.  Writes books about subject matter in these courses.

Although the exams can be challenging, the lectures are engaging and worth attending. Using resources like Unstuckstudy helped make the material more approachable. Overall, an interesting class with a fair workload.

The most disorganized prof ive ever had. Starts the semester off with every assignment as a 0, you have to work your way up, but then you never know what your actual grade in the course is at any given time. He has no idea how to navigate the carmen site and rambles through all his lectures. I want to jump through the screen to yell at him.

Crazy disorganized. It's clear he loves what he teaches but his lectures are just him slowly rambling, I can hardly process any of it. The weekly quizzes ask the most specific questions that have little to do with the actual importance of the course content, they feel like very clear "gotcha questions". Not to mention the unrelated PCA

No extra credit, harsh grading,16-page study guide that didn't help on exams. Ridiculous from an associate professor in a 3000-level course. He unlocked quizzes/exams on weekends (Friday night/Saturday night at 5pm) due that Monday evening. A very intelligent prof who has a passion for history, just don't know if the passion is for teaching.

Professor is nice but babbles through HOURS of lecture, weekly quizzes, course long project, midterm and final, an just over all not the easy GE I was hopping for. I dropped the class after week 1 but I put more time into this class than any of my nursing classes. The slides had barely any words so no help on quizzes just not worth the time!!!!!

Professor Grimsley was definitely not my favorite professor, but he was not bad. The class was pretty disorganized and I didn't really feel like I learned the most after completing the course. I found the class relatively easy, I just wish he put a little more effort into his lectures and his posts on canvas.

Not worth the trouble if taking as a Gen Ed. Class can be mildly interesting at times but the exams are pretty difficult. The prof is fine but as a ECE major I needed a gimme class and this is definitely not it.

Professor Grimsley was incredibly disorganized from the start. Week to week discussion posts and assignments are fairly interesting and very easy. The exams however are pretty damn difficult. CLASS IS NOT AN EASY A. Professor while VERY knowledgeable, inconsiderately fumbles his way though semester.

Do NOT take his classes, any of them. I've never done more work for a class and I'm a 25 y/o 4.0 student. He is mentally unstable and students bear the weight of that. He shouldn't be teaching. The people that left nice reviews had to have been bribed. He's SO DISORGANIZED and grades hard w/o feedback. He's also just rude. Insert profanity here.
His lectures are slow and boring. If they are prerecorded you can easily watch them at 2x speed and think they are normal speed. Overall, he made the content interesting and the class easy.

One of the best professors I have taken since I got here, He is an expert with countless years of experience in his field and tries to bring out the best in all his students. Is sometimes a hard grader but you will learn a ton in his class. Absolutely recommend.

Professor Grimsley cares a lot about his students doing well, so over the semester he would make changes to the class format based on student feedback. You have several lectures every week, two short quizzes, and a discussion post. It's not hard, and he designed it so you can't put it off to the end of the week and procrastinate.

Professor Grimsley is an ideal professor. He truly cares about his students and their wellbeing. He is very passionate about the material, which makes the content even more interesting to the students. The course is content heavy, but as long as you watch or attend the lectures you can easily achieve an A+.

Really great professor who genuinely cares about his students. I found his class to be very reading heavy and had a hard time staying caught up because of this, but I was still able to do well enough in the class. The material can be a little dry, but he's a great professor.
One of my favorite classes i have taken

Prof. Grimsley cares about the subject he's teaching as well as his students. He cares less about the history you learn and more of the reason behind it. His essays are very open ended and allow you to choose a side and defend it. These and the exams are the only grades, but the exams are very easy if you study your lecture notes.

I found his class to be very interesting. Attendance to lecture isn't mandatory is not required but I highly recommend going. He tests mainly on the key words he gives at the beginning of class. Very test heavy, only 3 grades (2 midterms and a final). Only truly need to read for recitation and right before the midterm essay. Overall great teacher!

Your grade will be comprised of 3 Exams, which are half take-home essay and half easy in-class MC/short answer. You will need textbooks but can get away with minimal reading. History majors, HIS CLASS WILL GREATLY IMPROVE YOUR HISTORICAL READING/WRITING ABILITY. also worth noting, I went on to take 3551 with him after how much I enjoyed 2550.
Smart.  Knowledgeable.  Specific.  Expert.  Sometimes short and condescending.

I took Several classes from Dr. G when I was an undergrad and grad student.  He is an excellent professor who knows his stuff but you have to put forth the effort and think for yourself;  you will not be spoon fed.  If you are not in to learning about military history, putting forth serious effort and or are looking for a PC safe space do not take.

Best prof. I have ever had at Ohio State. Took history of WW2 and wish I could take it again. Grade essentially consists of 3 exams (15%, 30%, and 50% of grade respectively. He is a true expert. Exams are pick what you want, for instance pick 1 of 6 essays.  I caution because I love WW2 history and if you have no background this class will be tough

One of the smartest professors I've had here. Learned a lot about the political/military/cultural part of the Vietnam war, and his tests were pick 4 of 12 short answer, etc. so you could focus on what interested you. He was slightly disorganized, but if you attend class/guest lecturers you will be fine. Definitely recommend this class!!
Please stay away from this class ... Just stay away

This is easily the worst teacher I've ever had in my formal education.  His lectures and lecture notes are unorganized, his exams test on things that were never discussed in class, and the TAs were two of the most condescending people I've ever met. Stay as far away from this class as you can.

Deplorable class. Nice man & respect his 2 silvestars, but, it is time for him to hang up the coat & enjoy life - to be respectful. I did NOT get anything from this class - NOTHING. I learned more from The History Ch & Wiki than him. This was suppose to be a Vietnam War class - we barely touched the war. AVOID THIS CLASS & PROF!

AVOID CLASS AT ALL COST Impossible to study for half the stuff on the tests are not in his workbook and his lectures are pointless because he just reads his note without elaborating then expects you to write a page essay about it.  I would avoid this class unless you already know a great deal about not only the Vietnam war but the entire  history.

Dr. Guilmartin is indeed an authority on military knowhow, but unless you are a history major or only interested in the military standpoint of the Vietnam War, please do not take this class.  I love history, but this class holds absolutely no valueable information for you to gain if you aren't in the marines or a major.  DONT TAKE AS A GEC!

Dr. Guilmartin was a fantastic lecturer who is clearly an authority on military history.  He also was kind enough to allow me to do an independent study to make up the last few hours I needed for graduation.  With that said, he is a bit disorganized and his lecture notes are not always up to date or relevant for his lectures.

Word of warning: the class was completely unstructured. Prof couldn't stick to syllabus, and was all over the place. Literally no one took notes by the end of the quarter bc it was impossible. He goes into tons of details and tangents and the powerpoint is useless. Had to rely on book, wikipedia and memorizing facts to pass this class.
I really enjoyed the content of this class, but the tests were pretty wretched.  ABSOLUTELY go see the TA's!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  That got me through the class!!!!

If you aren't interested in military type things-don't take this class. He teaches it completely military based. There is no useful guidance for the exams which are difficult. He wrote the textbook which is in shorthand notes that dont make sense if you dont already know stuff abt this topic. Basically taught myself thru google. Disappointment.

Simply the finest professor I ever had in eight years of college at four different institutions (including study abroad and grad school).  He's military, you're going to get military thinking from this guy.  The insights are priceless.

Expert and knowledgeable.  Interesting explanations about importance of certain countries' aircraft in World War II.  Also interesting is his personality explanations about famous people, such as Churchill, Roosevelt, Stalin, and Adolph the Hitler.  He is also a great maritime/ships expert and historian.

Awful. He is so unprofessional. I can't believe he teaches at OSU. His lectures are awful and half the time he is injecting his political views (right-wing conservative). He blamed FDR for making the depression worse (after reading several "convincing" conservative books). He even found a way to bash Jimmy Carter in a WWII class! Stay away.

If you do not like military-type things, do not take this course. Sometimes I felt as though I were in classroom at West Point. The powerpoint presentations and the book, his collection of slides, for the course are worthless. Half of the class used wikipedia prior to exams.

Very sweet old man who just happens to be one of the worst professors I have ever had.  His powerpoints are confusing and his lectures are boring and self-indulgent.  I learned more from the 9 books on Vietnam I checked out of the public library than anything associated with this class.  Plus, he likes to quote himself.
I took the class to to as an elective for my major and was surprised . He is one of the best professors I have ever had. He is not P.C and brought in good guest speakers.

I love WWII history and really looked forward to this class.  Unfortunately, this class was nothing like I expected.  Dr. Guilmartin taught the class from the militaristic point of view.  If artillery, battle tactics, ect aren't your thing DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!  Also, lectures are pointless--he digresses into random stories that don't help at all
Smart.  Knowledgeable.  Doesn't always know everything, however.  Doesn't like being corrected.  Expert, however.  Teaches good and clear writing and historic descriptions.

Super smart and loves the content she teaches. There are no Power Points so skipping class is very much not recommended. 3 book discussions say one thing and you get full credit. Doesn't use carmen at all so you won't know your grade until the end, but she doesn't really grade that hard. Overall good class and prof would recommend.

NOTE: History 2001H
Old school. Doesn't use Carmen at all, and the lectures are just her talking. This class was interesting, though, and a good light workload for an Honors GE. Besides a few in-class responses and discussions, most of your grade rests on the final, which was very straightforward. She also gives a thorough study guide for it.

Dr. Cashin was very patient and kind. There was a lot of reading to do, and she asks for a paragraph on each thing you've read. The essays you wrote weren't graded too harshly, and she gives you clear ideas of what to fix. The class is discussion based, so she doesn't teach that much but it works very well. Just come to class and do the reading!

She doesnt really teach, its discussions between you and your classmates. Shes more likely the moderator in the situation. That being said, shes one of the most understanding professors Ive had. Shell give you extended time for your work, she helps you out in any way so you understand the material. You wont use Canvas or know your grade.

Professor Cashin fails in every possible category when it comes to teaching. Rather than lecture, she relies entirely on readings and class discussions to "teach." Also, if she doesn't like you, you will not get better than a B. She seems to randomly pick who she likes and hates, and grades are subjective, so your grade rests solely on her mood.

Dr. Cashin is extremely knowledgable about American History in the 19th century and so her lectures are very interesting. If you come to class and read the three books she assigns, its is very easy to get an A. I am looking to take other classes from her in the future!

She is a more old school teacher. Very knowledgable on her subject, and she is really into writings. Lots of the grades you receive will be pass or fail, and the grades are never uploaded on carmen. If you skip class you will be screwed. Like majorly.

Joan is one of the most passionate professors I've had, so her lectures are very interesting. She takes attendance every class, so be there ON TIME. Her three short papers are easy--just read the book, write the paper, and participate, and you'll get full credit. Write down everything she says! The more you write on your final exam, the better.
Joan was brilliant. Her lectures were very interesting and as long as you show up and listen you should easily get an A. Very few assignments but all easy. I would be sure to take her classes again!

Prof Cashin is amazingly knowledgeable about her subject, and if you like American History then you should take her classes. No powerpoints, but taking notes is easy if you pay attention. Small discussions where you show up and say one thing. 3 books to read. Enjoyable and relatively easy, Prof Cashin is very likeable.

She is.... old school. Be ready to show up. Be ready to get called on if your eyes wander. No online material. The books you read are the type you can order on Amazon from goodwill  for 99. Which is nice. But also indicative of the dated material. She seemed nice enough. This is definitely not a show-up-and-pass course. Tests & seminars are TOUGH.

If you are serious about history, specifically Antebellum American and the Civil War, then take her classes and you will not be disappointed.  She is incredibly knowledgeable and well read.  You must go to class, she takes attendance everyday.   A really easy grader as long as you do the work. I take her every semester I can, she's great.

No actual textbooks, but 3 book discussions that are pretty easy. 3 short writing assignments that are passfail, 8-10 page paper, and a final which she gives you a study guide for. Pretty easy grader. Lectures can be somewhat dry sometimes, but overall I really liked her.

The easiest class I've taken in my life. The definition of an easy A. Take somewhat good notes and you'll pass.  Your grade consists of:  Couple group discussions (say one thing), attendance, like 5 one page papers, and a final (you write a paragraph explaining each key termeventperson).  She will give you a long study guide for the final.

Joan is a very oldschool professor. She's cool though, very knowledgeable. She expects you to attend every class. There are 3 book discussions, a final paper, and a final exam. Each is worth 20% of your grade. Show up to class, say one thing in the discussions, do the paper and study the guide for the final and you will probably get an A. Easy

As a Harvard graduate and student of David Donald Herbert, Dr. Cashin provides students with an unparalleled depth of knowledge. I am truly lucky to have had her as a Professor. If you are a serious historian then take her course. She is lenient on assignments and gives students many chances. If you do the readings and show up you should do well.

As others mentioned, she does kind of drone on. If you're interested in history, it's great, but she says a lot of stuff you won't ever see on a midterm or final. I probably only ended up using a third of my notes to study because most of it wasn't on the study guide. The midterm and final were supeeer easy, though, as long as you study the guide.

Dr. Cashin knows her Civil War history.  If you show up and listen during class, you will find yourself very knowledgeable about the subject.  There are three book discussions, and you have to find five primary documents and write five one-page papers about why they are interesting.  This was the easiest class ever, but I enjoyed it.
Boring class, but very easy
Cranky.  Whining.  Yes, obsessed with Catherine the Great.  Maybe he wanted to be the horse, lol.

A very caring professor who gives clear lectures and is very willing to answer any questions. His slides are pretty sparse though so note taking is recommended. He gives a lot of feedback on papers. Although some days had a lot of reading, he suggested just picking just one detail to share if there was a discussion, so it was low pressure.
Lectures are not mandatory but the discussion once a week is and you need to participate.

Professor Breyfogle is a very passionate lecturer, and uses this energy to clearly communicate the information to the class, and maintains the interest and attention of his students throughout the entire lecture. This was my favorite class this semester, and I would definitely recommend this professor!

He is very passionate about what he talks about. He is also very fair when it comes to expectations about assignments. Everything is clearly laid out on the syllabus. A warning though, even though lectures is not mandatory, the material in them will be crucial to meet the word requirements in the Final Exam so listen and take good notes!

Good dude, he makes it a really interesting class. The papers are hard and its graded really tough but you can get up to 10% of extra credit and the discussion section of the class is worth 30% of your grade so if you read and participate you'll get a good grade even if you don't do too hot on the papers.

The History of Water was one of my favorite classes I have every taken. Very interesting and unique. You write a paper every 2 weeks or so, but you have to read every week before discussion. Overall great class, not too much work

One of the better professors I've had, he is very devoted and passionate about the course material and gives interesting lectures, definitely learned a lot. Lectures are skippable but you must attend recitation every week.  Tests are all short answers and essay also a paper, managed an A without doing a ton of work & completing all extra credit

Breyfogle is a wonderful lecturer. He has lots and lots of reading. I'm a history major, and his class was maybe the most reading I've ever had. Lots of essays. He gave great feedback, but he expects a lot.

One of the best history professors I have had at OSU. The class subject matter is very interesting and Breyfogle makes it fun with clear and enthusiastic lectures. Discussion days as well. Class very paper heavy (determines most of your grade) and relies on the assigned novels. However, Dr. Breyfogle is very accessible and reads drafts beforehand

GREAT! Take his class, I took his Modern European history, great class and easiest A I have ever gotten. He offers 10% of final grade in extra credit (max score in class could be 110%) very easy, but very interesting. Great! Take it!

Professor Breyfogle was my favorite professor and I found a new interest in European history because of his enthusiastic lectures. He makes the class exciting and he is interested in the material. Study guides are terms that will be selected from for the tests, preparation is all you need for an A. Would HIGHLY recommend. Attendance is important

Prof Breyfogle made this class SO interesting because of his passion. He made this class so enjoyable. You HAVE to participate in recitation or you won't get a good grade. He hands out all the questions to the exams, which are short answers and essays, before hand so if you prepare well you'll do well. The books we had to read were interesting.

Amazing professor. Took 2204 as a gen ed and ended up loving the class because of Professor Breyfogle. Very educated on course matter and does more than read off slides. Doesn't put anything online so you have to attend class, but you'll be glad you did. Gives extra credit and easy to follow study guides for exams. Participate and you'll get an A

Professor Breyfogle is a great teacher.  I hate history and he actually makes the lectures interesting and fun.  He does not put lecture notes online so you have to go to lecture and listen, but he's so animated and passionate about history that it's nice to listen to.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. His lectures are very interesting and well organized and his sense of humor is great. He's always more than happy to talk after class too. He is a bit of a tough grader and the tests aren't exactly easy. You'll have a ton of reading too and if you don't do it you're screwed. I give this class 8.5/10

Prof. Breyfogle is awesome! His lectures are engaging, his sense of humor keeps things fun, and he moves through the material at a good pace. He is very clear about what he expects on tests and hands out the questions ahead of time. The reading assignments are really long, though, and he can be a tough grader at times. You have to work for it a bit

Prof. Breyfogle is a great instructor, his lectures are very engaging. The downside of this class was the huge amount of readings required how hard essays are graded. I spent twice as much time studying for this class and I didn't get the grade I expected. I don't recommend taking it if you have more than 12 credits.

Dr. Breyfogle was the best professor I have had at OSU. The lectures were always well organized and very interesting. He does expect a lot from you but the knowledge I gained made it very worth while. Great man, great class you should take it.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. Has a sense of humor, easy to approach. He takes the time to answer any questions and loves to talk after lecture. He even recognized me and said hello when I saw him at the library and I'd only talked to him once after lecture. His class WILL be demanding but he's more than happy to help.
Very excellent.  Knows the era.  Interested in students.  Good lectures.  Clear objectives.
Very nice.  Very competent and capable.

If u are a decent/good writer, you'll be fine. Lectures r long, can be interesting if u like pres elections. Doesn't have clear grading criteria, just ask & she grades pretty easily.  Very knowledgeable and cares about what she teaches. Ur grade will reflect wht u put into this class. As long as u put in a little time & effort, you'll be fine.

Super long, boring lectures that you have to pay attention to the whole time to get a decent grade. When you submit assignments she just responds with rhetorical questions, leaving you to feel like you always could have done better, even if you got a decent grade.

A really nice lady, and she does well in making sure you actually learn the content, instead of just having you memorize information, having you apply your knowledge to papers. With that being said, most of the course revolves around papers, and the quizzes were 60% extended response. The workload was small, but revolves around the papers.

Prof Baker is a good choice for a history class. I didn't know much about the Gilded Era going in, but knew a lot more coming out. Not overly hard classwork, but it can take some time. Pay attention in class and it's super easy to do the work.

Lots of papers but Professor Baker grades them leniently. MC quizzes are tough and reference readings which are dense and otherwise not necessary, but the short answer part makes up for it. Lectures are boring even if you are interested in Presidential History. She does um a lot but I didnt find it too distracting.
Her style isn't for everyone maybe, ask the right question and her answers were always very good.

Quizzes were multiple choice/short answer, but exams were all essays and she also assigned an essay, so this was fairly stressful. Lots of reading/books, some more important than others. She's great, and I got her sense of humor, but man was the class dull sometimes. Overall not hard to get an A, but not easy either.

Do the reading and go to class for sure she takes attendance. Don't try to answer with any original though or she will grade it tough. Just regurgitate her own opinions and you'll get a good grade. Very few grades so everythings weighted pretty heavily.
Nice lady.

Her lectures mostly consist of her rambling. Pretty much nothing happened in the Gilded Age and Progressive Era, so maybe that has something to do with how boring the lectures were. Overall, she was nice and seemed to want her students to do well. She grades fairly but the TA for this class graded much harder.

Prof. Baker knows the material very well but promotes class discussion more than lecturing.  Exams were essay-based and were always about things which were discussed for at least an hour in class.  If you are looking for a good history class with an easy A, go with Prof. Baker.

Interesting content, but her lectures are fairly dry. She uses "umm" a lot. Not a difficult class, assignment-wise. 5% attendance. Have to read a couple novels for the tests, which are short and succinct. Only 1 paper; graded fairly easily.
Says "Um" and "Uh" a lot.  Class was very dull

Took 564 and 566 with her.  She doesn't say 'um' anymore, but her lectures can be rather dry.  However, she knows her stuff and lets you know her expectations on all assignments.  She has review sessions for the exams where she goes over the possible exam questions one by one.  Exams are normally essay based but not too specific.

Overall, it was an easy A. In addition, I learned a lot about the Gilded Age and the Progressive Era. She only makes you write one, 5 page paper! Paper topics were bad but I still got a 100% (Just make sure you put effort into it). She doesn't really say "um" anymore so don't count that against her. Take her if you want to learn A LOT and get an A.
Paula Baker is a good scholar, a thoughtful teacher, and one of the most decent people I have met in the historical racket.

Baker is knowledgeable, interesting, helpful, and funny. Her lecture style takes some getting used to as she pauses a lot, asks leading questions, and goes onto tangents, but none of that negates the quality of the class.

Very knowledgeable professor.  Well organized, and knows her subject area.  The Titanic part of the final lecture was a chiller, one of the many unfortunate events that occurred on the eve of World War One.  All in all, this was a very interesting class (Gilded Age to Progressive Era), and I would recommend it to people who wish to study that era.
Good lectures.  Lots of reading.  Lots of paper writing.  Tough critic when grading papers, but well-meaning.

The only assignments for this class are 3 essays. He is a tough grader which I was intimidated by at first. If you go to his office hours and talk to him about your papers, he will grade them himself (instead of his TA's) and he will give you a much better score since it shows that you cared and put in the extra effort. Extremely nice guy!
Knowledgeable.  Expert.  Writes textbooks.  Interesting insights.

Very boring. Business history is not a fun topic and if you can get away with it, try taking something else. I thought this class would be about the development of business throughout history. Not so much, several isolated examples with less focus on the big piture. emphasis on early Japan, again not fun. Tough grader!!!
Very knowledgeable and interesting.  Kind of tough, but he knows his stuff and genuinely cares about students.  Very good profession in my opinion.
Nice guy, but really hard grader. I've never recieved a C on a paper until this class. He is so knowledgeable that he expects perfection in papers.
really great
His only 2007 comments:  Nice person.  Pretends he is too sophisticated, but deep down he is human and friendly.  A hard grader, but has interesting insights.  9/10

has a great knowledge & passion for class subject matter - uses multiple forms of media such as audio tapes & picture slides - so in love with himself & arrogant it can be hard to watch - taking classes in business before taking this one might be extra helpful - fair grader - watch your grammar/structure in papers - he's a character

Very pleasant professor.  Walking library of information.  He has experienced so much and is a true historian.  Most brilliant professors I have met lack personality/humor/sympathy, but Dr. Blackford is an exception.  What more can I say, a brilliant man with a great personality.

Terrific professor. He clearly loves the material, and has a pretty interesting and relevant personal past associated with it. Not the easiest grader ever, but he's honest and consistent. He's also really personable, and funny as all get out. Take his classes, you won't regret it.

knowledgable but ignorant. very unprofessional and rude when i try to speak with the TA, he would try and have me stay away and not talk about the tests.he immidiately assumes i didnt read the f-in book.if there are records of identifiying students taking out books from the reserved,they should check it out bc i took out books 2-3 times week.

He was a great prof-very knowledgable-applies history to real life circumstances-uses a variety of teaching tools-video,radio, overheads. A hard grader on papers but will help you if you ask. Definately take him!
For being a Non-Native professor teaching a Native American history class, he was very knowledgeable. He was really nice, and for an upper-division class, it was very fun.
No Comments

Well, I thought Mansel was a pretty neat guy. I stopped by his office hours one time and talked about his Japan travels, which was totally awesome to me, as I am love travel. Very intelligent man, would recommend his classes to all, cute Indiana Jones hat ;)

Wasn't thrilled at having to take a history class, but it was fascinating. I took classes from him in the 80's, have found the knowledge useful many times since-it gives you a perpective from which to analyze business past and present.  The comparative class has been useful too.  Highly recommended!
No Comments
Fascinating guy.  Kinda sexy, for older man.  Don't tell him I said so.  Tries his best at humor.  Showed us pic of when he was 20 year old college student.  Hilarious!
Helpful.  Charming at times.  Witty & urbane.  Publishes many books.  Expert at business history.  Twinkle in eye.  A great listener to sob stories.  Very nice person, lol.
Not always friendly.  A little sarcastic.  Not very enthusiastic.

I really enjoyed this class and learned a lot. This isn't your euro-centric AP history course, instead it is a well-through history class that encompasses a comprehensive history of America. You should def take her class if you want to truly learn about American history.
Excellent teacher. You should def. take her! You'll learn a lot about American history. This isn't your Euro-centric AP History crap.
She is awesome

I took Ms. Wu's Women's Studies: The American Woman's Movement. We read a book a week and then talked about it in student led discussions.  It was very interesting and I learned a lot, but it was a lot of work.  Also, since we only really met once a week, attendance was mandatory.  She had lots of extra credit opportunities.
Great professor, knowledgeable, and very helpful. Really enjoyed her class and the final project.
No Comments
I liked her, she made the class interesting and made us work together. Plus there was hot girls in the class so it made it more fun!
Powerpoint notes could have been better, but assigned readings were very interesting. Just be prepared to write alot. Good Prof all and all.
I think she's fabulous!  Very bright, helpful, assigns interesting texts, and understanding if you have a problem.  She really loves teaching, leads discussions well and is so nice.

The amount of reading for this class is extremely heavy, to the point of being unreasonable.  Prof tries to fit too much in too little time.  TA is the only one who does grading.  Loved the subject but the teaching style made it hard to enjoy.

Teacher overloads students with readings. Very unclear, when we go over readings she only replies " thats one way to look at it." Is there no correct answer?  There is when the angry TA grades papers and quizes, TA is grading with a vengence.  And only looks for her answers. Out of sync these 2 are.

Dry.  Boring.  Worked us way too hard.  Way too much trivia.  Interesting class, though.  TA was pretty well organized; I was impressed.  Not many professors get TAs to work with them.  Glad too see lots of guys in class, besides women.

Extremely nice professor, tries to interact with the class. Asian American history was a good course. Lectures were a little boring at times, but some topics were interesting. Midterm was easy (short answer & essay), and we had a final project (no exam)!
Very nice person, patient and learns everyones name.  Talks the entire two hours with no break, but is interesting and well educated in her field.
Teaches interesting classes.  Taught a class on social movements in the 60's and Asian American Women's History.  I learned a lot in both classes.  Take any class she teaches!
American Women's History.  Too much information overload.  Dry & almost humorless.  Nice person underneath it all.  Interesting final projects.  Good rapport in TA classes.

You should be ready to attend as many classes as possible as she does grade for attendance. We did not have many assignments, but she was understanding on the in-class assignments if you had an excused absence. I would recommend her to anyone looking to take this class.

Professor Soland's class is very interesting and she is kind. I really enjoyed the unique content regarding women and the Holocaust. The only negative thing about this class is the little amount of assignments, and how late she grades them. I would recommend doing the extra credit, even if you do not think you need it at the moment.
The class was really interesting and she was very engaging. The material basically framed the holocaust through a female specific lens, which I found very interesting. Would take again!

Prof. Soland is super knowledgeable and passionate. AUT23 was the first time this class was taught, so there were a few kinks to work out but overall, it was pretty good. That being said, she is a huge stickler about participation, but show up to class, do the readings, and discuss your opinion with her and your peers and you'll be fine.

Professor Soland is an extremely educated and caring person. If you struggle AT ALL, she will give you second chances, just don't shy away from asking her. She is incredibly understanding as long as you show an interest in what she is teaching. It's nearly impossible not to develop interest due to how engaging the material is within her class.

I had her for a seminar, so it was completely discussion based, and participation is graded. Her grading is a little difficult to predict, but in general it wasn't bad. There's a lot of readings, at least 3 lengthy articles a week, with 1 page papers due each week about the readings.

She gave us a Nazi sympathizer website to use as an academic resource. My class brought this to her attention, she said "I've never noticed that before." She also said that Belgium wasn't involved in World War 1. Couldn't pay me to take her class again.

Really easy class, it's only four papers. I wrote all of them in 30 minutes and got As. She's nice but can be a little confusing. She did have us write a paper using a website that was created by the daughter of a Nazi and the website was almost in honor of the mom so that was really weird.

I honestly don't understand all the negative feedback. Professor Søland was one of the kindest and most understanding professors I've ever had. There isn't that much required reading and she posts all readings on carmen. Discussion matters but her class is so engaging it's easy to participate. Overall, amazing professor.

I was surprised to see such low ratings for Professor Søland. She is light hearted and although shes a tough grader, she offers many extra credit assignments and very little homework. If youre looking for a relatively easy GE that covers two areas of study, History 2275 is the way to go.
Very harsh grader--doesn't curve. Participation is mandatory and is graded very highly.

I had her for History of Children and Childhood. Some of the information presented was interesting and thought provoking but most of it was not. Her grading was very unclear. Participation in class was a big part of your grade but she wasn't clear on how she keeps track/ counts the people that speak. Essays were graded fairly and no exams.

She was the worst teacher I have had in 15 years of schooling. She was not clear with what she wanted, graded insanely harshly, and would blame the class for her own mistakes. She put up "bad" responses of midterm questions in class and had us say what was wrong, without the permission of the authors of the answers (who were sitting in the class).

Some of my classmates had really bad interactions with her in and outside of class. She took points off for really random things on essays and exams and it was really unclear sometimes what she was looking for. No textbook so if you don't go to class, you're out of luck. I would avoid this class if you can.

First, just go. I had a hard time attending her class and it hurt me bad. Her grading system is a mess. She freaked out on our class a few times for her mistakes. Her class depends on what kind of student you are. If you like to speak often then you will enjoy her. If you are the kind of person who likes to listen, probably not for you. She's nice.

Grading is all over.  She said participation mattered, but many students spoke nearly every single day in class and still didn't pull full points on participation, so whatever she is looking for is unclear.  I typically get A's and am lucky to get out of here with a decent grade.  All grades were group projects, you WILL have to do extra credit.

Grading was very unclear, she only put one grade in for the semester and it ended up being my final grade. Participation is huge, I think there were 4 papers and participation that went towards the final grade. The class was not as interesting as I anticipated but professor soland was pretty passionate and very knowledgeable.

Took this as a May session class and it was very easy. No tests, just a group project every week and a final paper but she is pretty easy on grading. A big chunk of your grade is participation so be ready to talk during class. Overall good class and Dr. Soland was very nice and helpful.

Do not take her class. She is a controlling professor who is not helpful. Her grading makes NO SENSE and she takes her gen ed class so seriously its not worth your time. Also just boring material in general.

History 1152. Prof. Kraemer is insanely passionate about history and a great teacher. Hardly uses notes and can talk about anything. Extremely willing to work with students. Very nice ec offered. Attendance is mandatory. Extremely transparent on grading. Wants everyone to thrive. Couldn't recommend this class more!

Professor Kraemer is extremely nice and is very passionate about the class. (Intro to Native American history). The class was fun, but there were not a lot of assignments so do not miss them. Attendance mandatory but he is good about working with you to accommodate.

Basically graded on the two essays which are 60% of your grade, responses and hypothesis assignments based on the material of that specific week. I thought she was nice and even though my essays were horrible I still got an A-. The class is at your own pace and there are no penalties for late assignments, but you should start early and not rush.

As a person she is very kind and it's easy to see she loves history. That being said this class is ONLY on Christian Saints. Do not take unless you are interested in learning about Christian Saints, enjoy a lot of reading, and write well. Tedious weekly assignments (graded hard, no feedback) and no slides/structure for lectures... only listening

One of the best classes I have taken. The love she had for Medieval History was palpable and made class amazing. She doesn't teach it chronologically; she teaches thematically so there is some jumping in the timeline. But she makes sure things are grounded. 6 papers that are 5 pages, but you can skip one. Overall great class with amazing professor

I feel like a lot of the people here giving her poor ratings are people who took one of her classes as a GE and were upset it wasn't just an easy A. She is genuinely one of the most caring and compassionate profs I have met and loves when students come to office hours. There is a good amount of reading and writing, welcome to the humanities.
Overall very unhelpful too hard of a grader for meaningless classes. Treats a GE class like your studying chemistry. Good luck❤️

I regretted almost every single lecture, they had no flow, no outline. I went to class with a bit of confusion about the reading and ended up with even more. If you are a person who knows a lot about Jesus and the Christian faith and sainthood, you will pass, if you don't DO NOT take this class!

Most of the course was taught through three assigned books. Lectures didn't follow a timeline and were all over the place or provided a brief snapshot in Roman history. Hypothesis assignments didn't teach much.

Extremely nice, but never gives clear instructions for assignments and little to no feedback when grading. The lectures have no relation to what we're working/being graded on and the attendance is ridiculous. She either talks like the class is 10 or already has a PhD, and not a single demon was discussed.

Dr. Arnold puts effort into her pedagogy. She cares about skill building, learning outcomes, and the wellbeing of students. Classes are a mix of lecture and discussion breakouts. You must read and attend class to make the pace manageable and succeed on graded work, but there's no wasted effort. Great prof and a brilliant and lovely person too.

Great professor who cares about her students, there is one big textbook that she uses throughout the semester and then there are 2 others that are used to supplement the big one. weekly source responses, no midterm but there is a massive final exam that is 10 pages but she breaks it up into four different sections

Prof Otter was my favorite professor all semester and might be my favorite so far here at OSU. The lectures are long and some can be boring, but he tries to make them funny and his accent is hilarious. 3 essays for 60% of the grade all 3-5 pages. Final essay is 8-10 pages and worth 40%. First two essays can be re-written until they are a 100%.

The class was easy, with a total of 4 assignments. While the presentations were black text on gray backgrounds, he managed to make it enjoyable with his great sense of humor. I'd recommend this class and Otter if you need it for an easy elective/gened.

Pretty easy class, with four papers graded by the TA. If you didn't like your score on the first two, you could rewrite them. Otter has a good sense of humor and made the lectures that were comprised of "boring" information super engaging and interesting. Good class to take for a GE, or history credit.
Otter is an amazing professor, although I didn't particularly love the subject matter if you take Otter you'll learn and enjoy the class.

dr. otter cares a lot for his students. there are three 3 page papers and a 10 page final. you get unlimited rewrites on the first two. i took this as a ge and do not care about the content, but he made it enjoyable. i highly recommend if you dont mind writing

Professor Otter is top 3 of my favorite professors here at OSU. He makes the lectures interesting to learn about even though it's a history class. I have never written a ratemyprofessor review but I had to for him because he's the best history teacher I've had in a LONG time. Please take this class especially for a Theme course!

Great professor, very helpful and attentive. Learned a lot about a relatively boring subject (in my opinion) in a very interesting way.  Dr. Otter made what would usually be a very rough class to take one of the highlights of my day.

Chris Otter was hilarious, caring, and really made this class entertaining. I've never cared about history until this class! Your grade only rests on attendance and four papers though, so if you're not a good writer I would not recommend this course. It's also important to pay attention to the syllabus for the requirements for each of the papers.

Dr. Otter is awesome!  He is funny and keeps his lectures engaging by having class discussions.  Class has 3 shorter papers (3-5 pages) and one 10 page final paper.  The papers are graded hard, and the class takes a good amount of effort but if you put the effort in you will learn a lot!

Prof Otter is one of the best professors I have had at OSU. Even though papers can be a bit challenging, if you put a fair effort, he will give you a high grade. He's very friendly overall and he will make sure that you earn a fair grade based on the effort you put in.

Dr. Otter is a fantastic professor! Very knowledgeable about the history topics covered in the course. Course assignments consist of three shorter 3-5 page papers and one final term paper. He can be a tough grader, but he allows the first two papers to be rewritten. Be sure to utilize the readings in your papers; omitting them will hurt your score.

Professor Otter is very knowledgeable! He explained all of the material well for all of us to understand. I would say he was a tough grader at first but you're able to revise 2 of the 3 response papers. Assigns readings, but it goes along with what we learned in lecture. As long as you get used to how he grades and what he wants, you will do well!

Professor Otter is a great professor! Hes very knowledgeable and wants his students to succeed. However, he is also an extremely tough grader. I would not recommend this class if you want an easy A; youll spend a lot of time reading and writing. But if you want to get challenged and learn something new, Otter is the best person to learn from.

Professor Otter was a great professor, but his lectures progressively became less interesting. All students have to write their notes on paper (no electronics allowed unless SLDS) and it is beneficial when it comes to retaining information, but he talks really fast and does not leave his slides up for enough time.

Best professor ever. Attendance is mandatory but his lectures are amazing and you'll learn a lot. Three response papers and one final paper but he lets you re-write the first paper until you're satisfied and you can always ask him to read drafts and provide feedback. He genuinely cares about his students and works to make classes fun & interesting

Nicest professor ever!! Really cares about his students and is really willing to work with them regarding deadlines/assignments. Grades based on 3 papers each worth 20% of grade, 1 final paper worth 30%, and 10% attendance. No daily homework. Requirements of papers are clear. He tries to make the lectures as entertaining as possible

Chris cares so much about his students and it shows! Always responds to emails within the hour, sometimes less! Very personable & tries to gain student engagement. There is no electronics allowed in his classroom, but it is honestly beneficial because you use all your notes to write your papers. Very good guy, would recommend to anyone!

Dr. Otter was an amazing professor. He's very understanding of the fact that his students have many other obligations outside of his class. Assignments were very manageable. Grades in the class came from attendance and a few papers, but he allowed you to resubmit them as many times as necessary to get the grade you wanted. I would highly recommend.

Attendance was required, but the class is great. He was very interactive without making anybody feel awkward in discussions. There wasn't really any technology allowed and we took notes on paper, which helped me learn and retain information. There were 3-4 assignments total, all papers, but he was helpful and gave lots of feedback before grading.

He is absolutely FANTASTIC and EXTRAORDINARY. He is extremely intelligent and knows his fields of interests really well. Going to classes and listen to him lecturing in his beautiful British accent is just an enjoyment. If you pay attention to the paper requirements and do all the readings, you will learn a lot.
Interesting lectures, informative and fabulous reading materials.

This was a great summer course. It had about 2 lectures each week, about an hour long each, but you can easily take the weekly quizzes without watching them. The discussion posts only required a decent amount of effort because you needed to complete the weekly readings to answer the discussion posts. Only 2 papers for the class but he grades fair.

One of the best professors I have had at OSU. I took his History3216 class and it was amazing. He's a very engaging lecturer and a lenient grader. Quizzes and assignments were all very easy. His courses are worth taking without a doubt.
Super interesting class! Dr. Vanderpuy was great and helpful. There is a lot of reading though, many passages from different books (can be found online in pdf form of for a few dollars used).

Professor Vanderpuy is pretty average. I basically never saw the man because the class was asynchronous, but I can't hold that against him. Essays had really varied grading (although some were also graded by a TA), and generally rewarded 8th grade writing style over college writing. However, biweekly quizzes were a good grade boost.

Lectures are long with a lot of tangents/rambling. Material is pretty straight forward so as long as you take notes and pay attention to the lectures, you'll be fine. There are only a handful of assignments, discussions/quizzes/exams. I took it second session and I think the pace is definitely manageable.

Overall, Peter Vanderpuy is a good professor. The class structured around watching approximately 3 lectures videos a week (each at least an hour) with a easy 15 question quiz. There is 1 midterm, 1 paper and a final. Get ready to take lots of notes and write deep analysis papers for the paper midterm and final. Responds to emails quickly.

I took this as an 8-week session course, fully asynchronous online. His lectures were pre-recorded, but he still sent out emails and announcements often. The slides in the lectures were hard to follow, but if you listen to what he is saying and take notes from that, the textbook wasn't really needed. 2 discussion posts and an easy quiz each week.

Seemed really nice. Lectures were all prerecorded. Each week there were a few lecture videos, discussion posts, and a good bit of reading. There's about 6 pretty easy quizzes throughout the semester and you get two attempts for all of them. He also gives you potential midterm and final questions ahead of time. Grades essays generously.

Having taken this class, I thought it was a very easy and well organized. If you love history, you will do very well! Every week there was both a quiz and discussion posts. The quizzes are very forward and discussion posts are graded on participation. The final exam was a final essay 4 pages long. Overall, I would recommend!

Pretty straightforward class. Weekly quizzes are easy if you watched the lecture videos. Weekly discussion posts pretty much graded on completion. Essay based midterm and final are graded harshly so I would definitely put time into them.

Each week, there is a lecture and primary reading assignments, a short quiz, and a discussion thread. There is 1 midterm paper (2 page) and 1 final paper (4 page over two questions). I found this class extremely interesting and the lectures to be very accessible without background knowledge. Quizzes are super straightforward. Professor was great!

prob one of the easier history classes. i ended up not reading the book and did fine. as long as you watch the lectures with complete attention, you'll do good on the weekly quizzes. discussion posts are easy. midterm and final essays. lectures are kind of all over the place but again just pay attention.

You really dont have to use the textbook if you listen to his lectures he posts every week. pro tip: put it on 2x the speed and you'll be done with them in half the time. discussion posts and quizzes are not hard. Midterm and final can be graded semi-harshly and they are essay heavy. Just read the primary sources and listen to the lectures.
Dr. VanDerPuy does a great job at sending information and laying out what exactly he expects from his students. Follow his directions and you'll do just fine

This class had simple weekly quizzes but in order to do well on them you would have to listen to the lectures thoroughly. Also there was weekly reflections but those were easy. This class requires effort. Also the midterm was short answer and one essay question. The final was two essay questions. Overall I found this class pretty easy.

I took a class with Mr. Vanderpuy after seeing generally good reviews of him. However, his class was incredibly difficult, especially his weekly quizzes. Overall, Vanderpuy was not a good professor and I would not recommend that anyone take his class. Very disappointing

Class was almost completely discussion board based. Simple quizzes once a week and essay midterm and final. He seemed very enthusiastic and kind. Sent him an e-mail on the day our final was due, and he answered my question within a couple of hours. I used the book, but I probably could have gotten away with not using it. One of the easier A's.

Weekly discussion posts and quizzes with a midterm every few weeks. Lots of supplemental reading but its interesting and not necessary to be aware of every detail. Lectures are straightforward and interesting. Textbook is kind of dull but helpful.
Great professor, gives very informative lectures and is just amazing all the way around
really nice guy, super kind and easy to understand

Straightforward class, 2 exams, 1 term paper, and a participation/attendance grade. He posts a lot of readings on Carmen which you should look through to reference in your exams but otherwise not a bad class.

Easy class/GE because of the grading and way the class is set up. 1 paper, 2 midterms with cheat sheet and he gives the essays and possible ID terms before. Read the book, never went to class. His lectures are confusing, chaotic, and disorganized. Presents a lot of facts with little analysis or explanation of their significance.

I am a big fan of Professor Levi. His knowledge of the region is truly special and his personal accounts of many elements of the class make the course engaging. That said, it is a ton of reading and memorization. Also, the grading is very sporatic... I had a 96 until the day final grades were due with only 40 percent of grades in. Still loved it!

Mongol Empire is a good class, and I did take his other class, the Silk Roads. The movie days are just a punch in the face. Traveling over an hour by bus to get to class to watch a movie terrible. Just put it online, and I would watch it at home. There is so much to cover, and he doesn't cover all of it, making the papers and exams difficult.

you can get by skimming all 300 pages of reading each week. the syllabus says you have to buy 5 books, but only buy 4 out of the 5, if you are going to attend each lecture, don't need to buy the Peter Hopkirk book. great professor overall, but many classes were canceled. only grades are a 10-page paper, midterm and fina;, and extra credit optional

Awesome professor with a great personality as well - open to help if you ask for it. Lots of reading per week but not completely required to pass the class (can get by with skimming). Class is determined by a midterm, final, 10-page research paper, and map quiz, but not too strict with the grading. Amazing class and you learn a lot!

Lectures are good, when he shows up. Many lectures were cancelled, and two days were movie days.  Exams are mostly from the reading.  And there are 4-5 chapters and multiple research papers to read each week.

THERE IS A LOT OF READING, typically almost 200 pages a week, but the lectures are good. gives out good information during the lectures and is willing to answer any questions that students have. the course consists of a map quiz, a research paper (10 pages), 5 books, and access to the online Carmen page for secondary source information.
I will forever be grateful to have him as a professor. Haha Kentucky! Show up, do your part and he is very understanding. He really cares and very knowledgeable. Plus he hates ties so dont wear one��

Now, He is so caring and really wants his students to do well, but you have to want to do well. You have to read all the books he assigns in order to grasp the concept because his lecture is spoken. It's hard to know what is important. The only reason I did well was because I tried so hard for this class, especially for a GE. good luck.

Prof. Levi was one of the best history professors I've had. Very enthusiastic teacher who can make even dry and complex material interesting, understandable, and relevant. Definitely sparked my interest in Middle East history. (Simple) map quiz, midterm, final, and research paper. Gives helpful study guides a week before exams.

Super nice guy and is hands down the best professor i have ever had. Gets to know everyone on a first name basis and wants you to do well. Also super funny. Just go to class and take notes and you will be fine. Tried to take his other class but it was full :(

Levi is super knowledgable about the Middle East/Central Asia and incorporates lots of cool personal experiences into class. The lectures can be a little scattered without a powerpoint, but he gives a study guide before the exam. Exams definitely require studying but he gives you all the points he can. Helpful when it came to the research paper!
Professor Levi cares about students and is interested in your success. In class he is passionate about the material and tries to engage students. Absolutely wonderful professor!

Great professor. Engaging lectures, clear on information that is needed for tests, and overall an interesting man. Makes me look forward to the class and feel knowledgeable on the information when I leave. Very understanding and answers all questions expertly.

I had Breanna Miller as my TA and she was great. Biggest thing is to at least do part of the reading and participate once each recitation. It puts you in better standing with your TA if they know you are engaging in discussion. The tests weren't too hard, a terms list and 3 possible essays were provided beforehand to study. Take advantage of it.

i actually liked his lectures. exams were easy if you study. i got an A. all you have to do is go to his lectures and take notes. you will be good to go. oh reading helps too! some questions came from the book.

Lecture is all spoken, yes, but he always gives a list of terms at the beginning and it's not absurd to expect students to take notes during lecture. He's also VERY clear in what you need to know for the tests, gives a list of terms you need to know and a selection of essay questions, one of which will be on the test.

Professor Levi is a really cool guy, he tries to structure his class only on what interests students. He assigns books to read and my class did not like one of them so he told us we didn't have to read it. We only had one quiz (map quiz), one midterm, and one final (gives you essay prompts ahead of time). You also have to write an 8-10 page paper.
