Horrible. No structure of class, is definitly not clear in what he wants you to know from the class for the test. Lecture is all spoken and this make it very hard to comprehand the information because these are names no one has heard of. Interesting info, but the class is overall terrible

I LOVED THIS CLASS.  He is hilarious, and he is an expert on anything and everything having to do with Central Asia.  We watched lots of movies, but I actually learned things from them.  There was one 10-page paper for the quarter.  The class was overall quite easy, and I would wholeheartedly recommend this class for the Mideast/Near East history.
Very, very, very passionate about the topic. Very knowledgeable about it too. Lectures felt like story-time, can get dry but mostly enjoyable. Humor lightens class
Great professor
He's one of the most knowledgable professors I've had, and about an obscure topic.  Even when his jokes aren't funny, they lighten up the class and make it a lot easier.

Great class!!!For someone not interested in history at all, with effort i pulled an A so its do-able. He is a great lecturer and funny with good timing. Just dont sit in the back cause he tends to mumble a bit. Lecture is basically the exam so a smart person would attend. And dont procrastinate on the paper i did and i lost a lot of sleep!

Awesome! I didn't know anything about the Middle East before taking this class and I learned a ton from him. Readings are mildly helpful, but his lectures are extremely thorough. Definitely need to go to class to get an A. Very fair exams! Any class would be great with him. He loves what he teaches.
Prof. Levi is a great guy and teaches a straightforward class. He is flexible with students in addition to the fact that he's always looking for student feedback. Take his class if you can.

If you need to take 398 and Levi is teaching, TAKE HIS CLASS. He is a cool dude, really funny. Assignments were relatively easy to stay on top of, and if you have any writing skills, you will ace the class.
Great guy and a great teacher

Professor Levi is a great guy. He does everything he can to help and loves to teach. He does require a lot of reading in his class, but it it is fairly easy and if you keep up on it, you are guaranteed a good grade.

Professor Arnold cares a lot about the success of her students and a lot about the material she teaches. That said, the class was a but unorganized and sometimes what she wanted was unclear. I do not blame her, as she is still adjusting to OSU, and I think she is a great instructor. Ask her questions!

Basically graded on the two essays which are 60% of your grade, responses and hypothesis assignments based on the material of that specific week. I thought she was nice and even though my essays were horrible I still got an A-. The class is at your own pace and there are no penalties for late assignments, but you should start early and not rush.

As a person she is very kind and it's easy to see she loves history. That being said this class is ONLY on Christian Saints. Do not take unless you are interested in learning about Christian Saints, enjoy a lot of reading, and write well. Tedious weekly assignments (graded hard, no feedback) and no slides/structure for lectures... only listening

One of the best classes I have taken. The love she had for Medieval History was palpable and made class amazing. She doesn't teach it chronologically; she teaches thematically so there is some jumping in the timeline. But she makes sure things are grounded. 6 papers that are 5 pages, but you can skip one. Overall great class with amazing professor

I feel like a lot of the people here giving her poor ratings are people who took one of her classes as a GE and were upset it wasn't just an easy A. She is genuinely one of the most caring and compassionate profs I have met and loves when students come to office hours. There is a good amount of reading and writing, welcome to the humanities.
Overall very unhelpful too hard of a grader for meaningless classes. Treats a GE class like your studying chemistry. Good luck❤️

I regretted almost every single lecture, they had no flow, no outline. I went to class with a bit of confusion about the reading and ended up with even more. If you are a person who knows a lot about Jesus and the Christian faith and sainthood, you will pass, if you don't DO NOT take this class!

Most of the course was taught through three assigned books. Lectures didn't follow a timeline and were all over the place or provided a brief snapshot in Roman history. Hypothesis assignments didn't teach much.

Extremely nice, but never gives clear instructions for assignments and little to no feedback when grading. The lectures have no relation to what we're working/being graded on and the attendance is ridiculous. She either talks like the class is 10 or already has a PhD, and not a single demon was discussed.

Dr. Arnold puts effort into her pedagogy. She cares about skill building, learning outcomes, and the wellbeing of students. Classes are a mix of lecture and discussion breakouts. You must read and attend class to make the pace manageable and succeed on graded work, but there's no wasted effort. Great prof and a brilliant and lovely person too.

Great professor who cares about her students, there is one big textbook that she uses throughout the semester and then there are 2 others that are used to supplement the big one. weekly source responses, no midterm but there is a massive final exam that is 10 pages but she breaks it up into four different sections

Mansoor is a great professor and is very knowledgeable and experienced on the topic of American Military History. This was just for my GE, but I ended up learning a lot and really enjoying the class.  Go to lectures and do the readings and you'll be good.  2 essays on the material as exams, 3 req books w/ essays, random graded attendance, and ex cr

Great professor who is very passionate about what he is teaching. Lectures can be very tedious and boring but overall have good info. TAs grade papers VERY tough, a midterm, final, and 2 book reviews and 5 random attendance checks. There was extra credit so that was nice. Overall not bad but only take if you rlly want to know in depth ww2.

Mansoor gave great and super thorough lectures, so if you paid attention, the essays were not terribly difficult, substance wise. The essays sometimes were difficult to write in the time span given, so you have to plan out your time pretty well. The TAs grade pretty harsh too, but use your notes and you should be fine.

Incredible course taught by an incredibly knowledgeable man. Could not have asked for a better experience in the class. Very few assignments - just a handful of essays that require you to be concise more than anything. Highly recommend to anyone interested in WWII, earning a history degree/minor, or looking for a fun but unburdening class.

If you're not smart like me but have work ethic you will pull an A- / B+. Study the study guides very well, didn't read much at all, pay attention in class, take more notes on what he says than the slides, Youll do fine

Peter is okay. His lectures are insightful for sure, just kind of boring. He is pretty full of himself and very opinionated. For example at one of his extra credit debates he was supposed to be a moderator and instead of doing so he interrupted one of the people debating to give his own opinion and shut the other persons down. His jokers are funny.

Professor Mansoor is by far my favorite professor at OSU. His lectures are worth attending even though they are not mandatory (he also takes random extra credit). Pay close attention to the rubrics and syllabus, and if you miss points on the papers make sure that you find out why to fix it, as some graders are pickier than others.

The best professor I have had at ohio state. Would take again, eish i still had the oppurtunity to take another one of hos classes. You have yo do the work, but theres no suprises and you know how your going to be graded. Amaxing man and amazing prof.

If you're interested in military history and you show up, you'll enjoy the class and do well. Professor Mansoor's knowledge and experience make his lectures very interesting and I learned a ton in his class. It is a lot of reading but you don't always have to do it, and the exams aren't bad.

One of the best professors at OSU. Sure the papers are difficult, but the books were so good and as long as you put in the extra effort you should be fine. The tests were straightforward from the study guides and they do grade the essays hard so prepare well for those. All in all, he is a wonderful professor and I can't recommend him enough!

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had at OSU. He is highly qualified for this job and his background makes his stories interesting and relative to course material. His dry sense of humor makes an already interesting class even more enjoyable! Read the book review books and follow the tips on Carmen and you will be fine.

He is probably the best professor I have had at OSU in my four years. He has an immense knowledge for the subject and makes the material very interesting. Not to mention, he is very respected in the historical community and in our government in general. If you have the chance to take one of his classes I would highly highly recommend it.

One of the poorest professors that I have ever had. He clearly knows what he is talking about but he speaks at you, not than to you. A former army officer and you can tell based on his better than you attitude. (Typical military officer). He reads off his own script that he wrights and spits info at you rather than teach you the information.

Lectures are excellent, Professor Mansoor is one of the most knowledgeable professors I've had, presents the class in an interesting way. Excellent credentials; if you like history you want to have the opportunity to learn from this guy. Exams require a good deal of studying, but you'll know exactly what's on the exam before hand.

I took his freshman seminar (Wars of 9/11) and I'm very glad I did. He is very knowledgeable of the material (and I mean VERY). It was incredible to learn from his perspective about modern Middle Eastern affairs. For his class we had a group project, a book report, and weekly class discussions. I learned a lot from him!

I had Prof. Mansoor for a Freshman seminar (Wars of 9/11) and it was extremely interesting. He is one of the most intelligent people I've ever met. He graduated first in his class at West Point and has more valuable military experiences than nearly anybody around. He knows what he is talking about, and has a sense of humor. Outstanding Professor!
Graded like an English class and very very military focused. Don't take this unless you have to

I loved Prof. Mansoor. His class was boring at first, but got a lot more interesting as we started talking about more current history. He makes jokes and adds a lot of quirky stories to his lectures. You have to write a book review, which was very tedious but I got an A. Two tests, studied hard and got an A on both. Challenging but enjoyable class.
He brought a lot of personal experience to the class.

I thought this class would be interesting but it was a very technical class. I found the reading difficult which also made it difficult to write the papers and essays since  I couldn't understand the reading. Prof. has a lot of military background which makes lectures and notes hard to understand if  you aren't familiar with military terms.

Fantastic professor and one of the best classes I've taken thus far at OSU. He makes all of the topics very clear and draws from an extensive military background to enhance lectures. However, there are book reviews assigned and they're graded very hard, so if you're not a solid writer it may be tougher. Tests are straight from the study guide
He comes off as being able to kill you at least 200 different ways and has a dry sense of humor that keeps lectures fun

Even as a history major, I thought this class was very difficult. It is graded in the form of an English class: there are two book reports and several essays on each exam. Also, do not make the mistake that I did thinking that this is a history of World War II. It is actually very military based, which I was not interested in at all.

He is a good professor but why in the hell is writing book reports the most important thing in a History class. I would not recommend taking the class unless you are a very good writer, they grade very hard.

Prof was very educated on WWII and has ppts posted online from day 1, which makes it easy to look over notes. I did little reading for the class; much was assigned. Read the books for the book review and follow advice posted on Carmen to do well. Exams followed his provided study guide 100% and there we no surprises. Easy class and pleasant prof.
Very interesting lectures. Book reviews were graded tough, along with exams.  Content was great along with the professor's background in the military.

Phenomenal lecturer with tons of real world experience. He's very passionate about the subject and is extremely helpful when it comes to grading and preparing for exams. TA's do most of the grading, and are usually very available despite the larger class. Would recommend to anyone.
Very good professor. Super interesting class. Attend the class, and follow along in lecture and you'll be fine!

He's always open to questions, very organized, and he's really good at getting the facts across in an interesting way! You can definitely tell he knows what he's talking about, and his humor makes the class even better! I definitely recommend taking this course!

He's great! The class was very strategic focused but he made it easy to understand. I was already extremely interested in the subject so that helped too. Assignments weren't horrible and his humor really made the class enjoyable.
Great class and great professor!

One of my favorite classes I've taken so far. Respectable guy. I learned a great deal from this class- the lectures were very clear, and he stayed consistent with the slides/syllabus (very organized). The exams are difficult, but if you attend class, take good notes and study, you won't regret taking the class!
Great teacher and teaches a great class.  If you attend lecture and do the work you'll get a good grade.  He gives you a study guide that the test pretty much comes from. I loved this class.

I found this class to be extremely hard, even though I am a history major. You must attend all the classes and read all the texts, which is mind numbing and very time consuming. This is because he assigns roughly 150 pages a night, not including the 3 extra book reviews you have to write. Unless you do exactly what he wants, expect a low grade.

Prof. Mansoor is a great professor. He really knows his subjects and is incredibly helpful. I didn't really use the books in either class I took, but they can help you some on the tests. Make sure to follow his guidelines on papers to the letter. You will have to work for a good grade on the papers but the tests aren't bad at all.
He was a fabulous professor. Definitely recommended. He is passionate about history regarding the military. You will have to work for your grade but if your a history buff as I am...great class!

I had Professor Mansoor for the History of WWII. He made the lectures very interesting, and had a comedic flair that kept the class constantly amused (the man does a hilarious Hitler impression). However, he has a high standard of grading, and what may get you an A in someone else's class may only get you a B. I'd recommend attending all classes.

The class is tough. Read the book, all lectures are based off of every chapter of the book, if you don't read and never find this out your a moron. Go to class and make sure it is clear in exams.  Not hard if you do these things

I had Prof. Mansoor for both 307 and 582- and I'm not a History major or military enthusiast. Not only did I learn a lot, but my writing also improved as a result of the class.  You will definitely have to work for your grade, but it is worth it!  I highly recommend either class.

I really enjoyed this class. Not an easy grader at all,   but he knows so much about military history and he always had interesting comments and stories to share. I would recommend this class, but you definitely have to be interested in WWII!

If you're not an ROTC geek or Historian then RUN AWAY NOW!!! I would rather see Dr. Kavorkian than see Dr. Mansoor. This is only for ate up military folks. If you don't wear camoflauge underware this isn't for you.
Professor Mansoor is an interesting teacher. I felt like I learned a lot from his class and would recommend it to anyone interested in taking it.
He's very clear and to the point. He's interested in the topic and knows what he is talking about. I would definitely recommend for someone to take a class that he teaches.

I think he is a good professor overall. He does tend to read straight from his notes, though I doubt it's Wikipedia - he is a Colonel and knows what he's talking about. It can make it slightly boring, but still interesting if you like WWII, and I have learned a lot. He doesn't tolerate dumb questions or sleeping in his class - he'll kick you out.

As someone who only hopes to be a Marine officer, I was extremely intimidated by him at first. Then, I realized how awesome of a guy he is. His jokes are a good break from his lectures. The lectures are very lengthy and contain a ton of information. Take a ton of notes to do well on his written finals. 350 characters does not give him justice.

Prof. Mansoor is a very interesting guy, and he's really blatant about mistakes made by military and political leaders. The material is really fun to learn, and Prof. Mansoor chose interesting books for the course. I would definitely recommend this course, and this professor.

Overall the content of this class was very interesting. It was a mix of powerpoint lectures and documentaries. There was reading but I never got to it. Even the comparative book review I just skimmed the books. The exams were straightforward but the final exam was way too long. I would say 75% of the class was still there when the exam time ended.

Must take class for anyone interested in WWII. The lectures were very interesting with the pictures and the documentary footage. Both exams are straightforward, he tells you what to study and if you study the terms you should do fine. No textbook, just powerpoints. My only complaint is the required reading is unrealistic, way too much.

Professor Mansoor is pretty awesome. Lectures can be pretty boring, but he shows alot of movies, trys to be funny at times, and always takes the time to help. The only downside to this class was the TA. She seemed to enjoy showing off how much she knew and talking down to people like they were 5 year olds rather than actually helping.

WONDERFUL class! Need to go to lectures because his slides are just a backhbone, but very interesting. Only a midterm/paper/final--but a study guide is given for the midterm and final. Paper is fine if you do the readings. A must take for a histsory major or anyone interested in WWII.
Great.  Expert.  Knowledgeable.  Caring.  Folksy comments; all good.  Don't try to correct him.  He knows a lot of good things.
Excellent.  Creative.  Gives good feedback.  Interesting lectures.  Writes books about subject matter in these courses.

Although the exams can be challenging, the lectures are engaging and worth attending. Using resources like Unstuckstudy helped make the material more approachable. Overall, an interesting class with a fair workload.

The most disorganized prof ive ever had. Starts the semester off with every assignment as a 0, you have to work your way up, but then you never know what your actual grade in the course is at any given time. He has no idea how to navigate the carmen site and rambles through all his lectures. I want to jump through the screen to yell at him.

Crazy disorganized. It's clear he loves what he teaches but his lectures are just him slowly rambling, I can hardly process any of it. The weekly quizzes ask the most specific questions that have little to do with the actual importance of the course content, they feel like very clear "gotcha questions". Not to mention the unrelated PCA

No extra credit, harsh grading,16-page study guide that didn't help on exams. Ridiculous from an associate professor in a 3000-level course. He unlocked quizzes/exams on weekends (Friday night/Saturday night at 5pm) due that Monday evening. A very intelligent prof who has a passion for history, just don't know if the passion is for teaching.

Professor is nice but babbles through HOURS of lecture, weekly quizzes, course long project, midterm and final, an just over all not the easy GE I was hopping for. I dropped the class after week 1 but I put more time into this class than any of my nursing classes. The slides had barely any words so no help on quizzes just not worth the time!!!!!

Professor Grimsley was definitely not my favorite professor, but he was not bad. The class was pretty disorganized and I didn't really feel like I learned the most after completing the course. I found the class relatively easy, I just wish he put a little more effort into his lectures and his posts on canvas.

Not worth the trouble if taking as a Gen Ed. Class can be mildly interesting at times but the exams are pretty difficult. The prof is fine but as a ECE major I needed a gimme class and this is definitely not it.

Professor Grimsley was incredibly disorganized from the start. Week to week discussion posts and assignments are fairly interesting and very easy. The exams however are pretty damn difficult. CLASS IS NOT AN EASY A. Professor while VERY knowledgeable, inconsiderately fumbles his way though semester.

Do NOT take his classes, any of them. I've never done more work for a class and I'm a 25 y/o 4.0 student. He is mentally unstable and students bear the weight of that. He shouldn't be teaching. The people that left nice reviews had to have been bribed. He's SO DISORGANIZED and grades hard w/o feedback. He's also just rude. Insert profanity here.
His lectures are slow and boring. If they are prerecorded you can easily watch them at 2x speed and think they are normal speed. Overall, he made the content interesting and the class easy.

One of the best professors I have taken since I got here, He is an expert with countless years of experience in his field and tries to bring out the best in all his students. Is sometimes a hard grader but you will learn a ton in his class. Absolutely recommend.

Professor Grimsley cares a lot about his students doing well, so over the semester he would make changes to the class format based on student feedback. You have several lectures every week, two short quizzes, and a discussion post. It's not hard, and he designed it so you can't put it off to the end of the week and procrastinate.

Professor Grimsley is an ideal professor. He truly cares about his students and their wellbeing. He is very passionate about the material, which makes the content even more interesting to the students. The course is content heavy, but as long as you watch or attend the lectures you can easily achieve an A+.

Really great professor who genuinely cares about his students. I found his class to be very reading heavy and had a hard time staying caught up because of this, but I was still able to do well enough in the class. The material can be a little dry, but he's a great professor.
One of my favorite classes i have taken

Prof. Grimsley cares about the subject he's teaching as well as his students. He cares less about the history you learn and more of the reason behind it. His essays are very open ended and allow you to choose a side and defend it. These and the exams are the only grades, but the exams are very easy if you study your lecture notes.

I found his class to be very interesting. Attendance to lecture isn't mandatory is not required but I highly recommend going. He tests mainly on the key words he gives at the beginning of class. Very test heavy, only 3 grades (2 midterms and a final). Only truly need to read for recitation and right before the midterm essay. Overall great teacher!

Your grade will be comprised of 3 Exams, which are half take-home essay and half easy in-class MC/short answer. You will need textbooks but can get away with minimal reading. History majors, HIS CLASS WILL GREATLY IMPROVE YOUR HISTORICAL READING/WRITING ABILITY. also worth noting, I went on to take 3551 with him after how much I enjoyed 2550.

This is a great gen ed.  Professor Grimsley is a good professor, I found his lecture very interesting and even looked forward to gong to his class. The only grades you will receive are the 3 exams (the final is not cumulative), which consist of a take-home essay and a short in-class mc/fill-in-the blank test. Class average was a B- on them.
Tough Grader. Really hard to pay attention in his class. He gets off topic a lot but really knows his information when he does talk about the lectures.
Excellent professor.

Not a history of war class! Just Grimsley's philosophy on the warrior code and his personal life struggles. Doesn't matter if you understand the overall concepts of the class; you better know the tiny details and people he mentioned one time. Took this class to boost my GPA and it ended up doing the complete opposite.

I loved this class! I went to almost every class even though attendance wasn't mandatory. He gives extra credit often - so definitely go to class! The in-class quizzes to go along with the written exams were based directly off of what he says in class. Exams aren't hard, but not super easy either. Definitely have to read 2 books, but they're quick!
His class is incredibly boring but if you don't write down every word he says you will do terrible on exams. He looks for specific words in responses and if you don't include them you will do awful.

I would agree with whoever said that you want to do well in this class just so you don't disappoint the guy. Each lecture is like a conversation with someone who is passionate and knows their stuff about history.

Took grimsley for 2001 course. Such a cool professor. Really chill guy and he made lectures interesting. Your grade consists of three exams all of which are take home essays which is awesome. You have to read a couple of the course books to do the exams well though so be prepared to read two books. His classes are very manageable. take him if u can

This class is NOT about the History of War. It is a philosophy class with much of the debate centered on something called the warrior code Dont be deceived by "History Of War" when signing up for this class Yes Professor Grimsely is a personable guy and can be entertaining But if you actually want to learn about actual war history find another prof
Really good guy and a fantastic professor. He keeps the lectures very interesting and is genuinely passionate about the subject.
Pretty easy teacher, there were three exams that were all very wikapediable.
He is very good at lecturing and gives interesting new insights. Class is relatively easy, if you're a good writer you will make an A.
Good lecturer overall, and a really nice guy to boot! Definitely knows his WWII history.

Great professor and great class. He really enjoys teaching, and he gets his points across very well. Basically, if you go to class, you're set to get a good grade. He does have some chauvinistic attitudes toward women in the class since it's Military History, but for the most part, he treats his students well and cares about their opinions.
Good professor.  Likes the students and the subject matter.
Excellent at lecturing and explaining.  Vast knowledge of military historical subjects.  Enjoys interacting with the students.
The only professor I have ever seen get a standing ovation at the conclusion of a course.

I have had him for two classes and he is a fantastic teacher... whoever typed he is a civil war specialist out of his league is retarded... for one hes a military historian and he was very knowlegable in ww11. I also agree that he was great but his ta;s suck... inconsistent grading and very hard to get a hold of
His quizzes are rather annoying but his history of WWII class was rather easy. I put in minimal work and received a B+
I am just about finished with his WW II course. Grimsley's a Civil War specialist who is hopelessly out of his depth in teaching WW II.

I really enjoyed the class. I do believe there is something wrong with the way the TA's grade in the course I took. I am unsure of why they are allowed to grade the way they do. Prof. Grimsley is very interesting and polished. Thumbs down for the TA's.

Grimsley is the kind of professor that makes you want to try that much harder just so that you don't let him down. The flair he brings to every lecture is inspiring. He certainly is not an easy professor; he expects alot out of his students. I highly recommend taking his course, (his WWII course is fascinating.) He is simply a great professor.
Grimsley's class is filled with an overemphasis on bizarre illustrations, bizarre overemotional outbursts, and generally inappropriate behavior.
Very enthusiastic in lecture, relatively dry and boring information made bearable through his interesting style of teaching. I actually enjoyed going to class!

While he was a decent lecturer, able to speak well the whole class period, his class was still too boring for its subject matter Plus his tests suck, each fill in the blank question is 4% of your grade so if you forget one word, there goes your chance of getting an A because the TAs also grade the essays arbitrarily, docking you 5 pts for nothing.
Very informative and educational. Enjoyed his lectures and teaching style. A++

Loved the class!  took a subject I've never really enjoyed and made it fun and interesting.  Very animated lecturer and dedicated to what he does.  Reading material is a little on the heavier side-but hey you're in college-keep up and it is likely you'll do well.  Definately one of my favorite professors at OSU over the past 3 years. Learned alot!

Powerpoints are often basic ideas of lectures, making you have to actually pay attention.  Reading was practically useless, I got a B+ without ever opening half of the books. He is very passionate about the information, but sometimes gets off topic for a long time.  Tests suck.  Multiple choice are random info. and one miss is half a letter grade!

fantastic teacher. he's energetic, fun to listen to, there were days that i was actually excited to go to his class because he is truly entertaining and you will learn a lot from him. i definitely recommend taking his class if you have the opportunity.
I thoroughly enjoyed his class.  He was very interested in teaching and lecture was enjoyable.  No homework. Exams are fair.

Great Teacher! understand concepts, not spew facts. Go to class, notes not on Carmen. Textbook not necessary(if you go to class), but get the correct editions of the other books. Exams: MC, Fill in, Essays; prompt given beforehand, the rest is easy. Study Guides great. Really enjoyed the class. if you don’t care, don’t take, you'll just get angry.

This class was pretty interesting considering the material that had to be covered. He seems to love this time period especially the civil war. When he talked about James Buchanan he reminded me of Lewis Black (the comedian). The book really is not necessary b/c it does not necessarily cover what he does in lecture. However, buy the assigned novels.

I was kind of skeptical after reading some of the comments here, but he's apparently improved since they were written. Lectures aren't terrible and the exams aren't too hard. Only thing that's bad about his class is there are 3 books including the textbook that need to be read, so you might be under stress if you've got some other hard classes.
Very energetic, has a serious passion for the subject and generally communicates clearly.  Also, don't be late, he doesn't appriciate it much.
I like his class, topic is boring but he is energetic. he has crazy policies, don't be late. but besides that its an ok history class.

i really enjoyed going to this class. he always kept my attention and made his points clear. the tests were a little tough, but fair. he did get off topic occasionally, but mostly want pretty interesting and he definitely knows his stuff. i'd recommend him to anyone who wants a class that is difficult to sleep through and wants to actually learn.

Seems to genuinely care about teaching the class, i.e. he does not just read off of overheads and ramble on for two hours.  Also. he uses media like power point and dvd clips to help enhance the class.
Amazing.  He is an absolutely amazing lecturer!

Interesting class, warfare truly does differ between society's, tests are multiple choice and essay, mc can get really difficult since the text has a lot of info, and i mean a lot, essays or something relating to them are revealed before exams,can be easy, but difficult to bs TA's grade a bit unfairly (and won't give back your final after 5 emails)
hard to stomach.
Very good history teacher! Try to get into his class if you can.

This class isn't hard, but it wasn't particularly interesting either. I was personally offended by several things that happened in the class (such as bringing in a preacher to "talk about seperation of powers" that mostly bashed gays, abortion rights and women). But the worst part of the class was that he was just not a very good teacher.
This guy is great. He was a really fun teacher and extremely interested in his subject material. I would take another history class with him!

This class was okay except that he seemed totally disinterested in the students. Pick someone else if you can.

"Caveman to Al-Quaeda".  History of War.  Not American Revolution and U.S. Civil War, but ancient China, Greece, Egypt, and early caveman conflicts.  Ancient warfare lectures always led to comparisons with current Iraq War, in that wars are still fought over needs, wants, money, religion.  Ancient weapons and fighting philosophies were studied.

Does his part as a teacher. Genuinely wants the students to learn and understand. Talkative, interactive, works to hold attention of students. Makes boring lectures interesting, fun, and amusing. Tests fairly easy. Gives extra credit. Truly doesn't want the students to get a bad grade. Approachable, friendly, knows a great deal about history.

If you're looking for a connection between religious fundamentalism in the 20th century and religion in the early part of the U.S's existence, you won't find it here, despite Grimsley's rather pathetic attempt to make the shoe fit. Kind of a crazy dude. Like, for real.
Excellent lecturer.  His powerpoints were a good guide to what he was speaking about.  He is very willing to help students during the breaks and outside of class.

Great teacher.  He keeps it interesting in lecture and the tests aren't that hard at all.  He literally gives you the essay topics on the study guides he makes up before the exam.  The reading is substantial, but not unmanageable at all.  Overall, he might be the best professor I've had at OSU and I'd highly recommend taking a course from him.

I love the assertive style... and the aloofness... makes me believe what you are saying.  You can definately tell how much Prof. Grimsley LOVES and is absolutely passionate about history.  That is what true teaching is.

An excellent professor, if the student is willing to listen and put forth their share of the work.  He makes the class interesting and teaches history the way it was meant to be taught, if you talk to him one on one he is one of the most understanding professors you will ever have.

Prof. Grimsley is to excited about his subject - it interferes with the ability of students to actually learn.  He also has chosen to grade a 100-level class in an inappropriate manner.  He is not cognizent of the size of his class, and delegates too much responsibility to his TAs, re: grading.

The grading is absolutely ridiculous. I feel  the test is not reflected of the study guide or notes and that the essays are graded WAY TOO HARD! If you have the main point that should be it- I mean come on you only give us 30 min!!! Some TAs grade harder than others. It just is not fair in anyway.

Prof. Grimsley is passionate about his area, however, he seems to think everyone knows zilch about American history and politics. The class is not too difficult. But I do get a little agitated when he tries to lump students together as if we are all uneducated "mooches" of society. Also, don't diss him on this website. He gets off on it.

How can you say he doesn't care about the individual.  A girl asked a question in class one day, and he came back next class with tons of information for her.  How many other teachers would take the time?  His notes are easy to follow and I feel when he stays on topic well.

One of the best professors yet! Makes history very interesting and easy to learn. His passion for the subject is easily seen through his lectures; it is refreshing to still see some life left in professors these days. Honestly, this is my favorite class. (AND I HATE HISTORY!!!!)

i think he's helpful.  if you want someone who knows his stuff and doesnt teaches for a reason, then take this guy.
Enthusiastic professor that often goes off topic. class is easy if you read the book.

Good prof who really knows what he's talking about. The only problem is that TA's grade our exams, which are bluebook, and I feel they grade way to hard for a 100-level survey course. Good Prof. sometimes gets wayyyyyy off the subject

Very nice and easy going guy.  Had little trouble relating to students.  Aided lectures by inserting film clips to visually demonstrate ideas.  Midterm and final study sessions especially helpful.  Is enthuastic about his work.  Enjoyed going to class.

A nice guy and all but I didn't learn too much in this class, but how can anyone expect to cover the History of war in 10 weeks?  The exams aren't too bad, but make sure to write A LOT on the essays even though the instructions say not to.  If you write a short essay you will get a poor grade.
Very good teacher
great lecturer - he knows his stuff and he speaks very well. lots of reading assignments (3 books, online sources), but its not so bad. i leave his class wanting to be a history major.
Definitely knows his subject well- GREAT lecturer, very animated-- dense material. This is not an easy class- you need to be there for every session. His tests are pretty difficult.
This man is my hero.  If I wasn't so close to graduating, his class would have made me consider changing my major to history.

Going out on a limb before I get the final grade, but so far he is excellent, caring, and a jokester who uses his enthusiastic illustrations (and background loud music) to make his points.  He tries very hard to make a sad subject very interesting.

does not email students back. does not reconsider any opinions that arent his. but still an excellent lecturer. Our class gave him a standing ovation after the last session and he deserved it.
Grimsley made me love History.  I used to get physically ill just thinking about this subject.  His lectures are very lively and interesting.  Definitely my favorite teacher at OSU so far!
I loved his class- great lecturer- I recommend his class

hey if you want a fun, charismatic teacher who never goads his inteligence over yours..take one of his classes. In a previous class, he opened the lecture in a huge hall, with dark lights Pink Floyd blasting. It was fabulous!
really intertaning in class

one of the top 3 profs i have ever had in all my years at OSU.  puts more effort into his lesson plans than any teacher i have had.  loves to illustrate historical points with films...very cool

This guy is a great teacher. He says all kinds of nutty things to illustrate his points. My favorite was the Lothar of the hill people bit when we were studying Charlemagne.
Prof. Grimsley is an outstanding teacher who is very knowledgeable and animated.  I learned a lot from his History of War class.
Smart.  Knowledgeable.  Specific.  Expert.  Sometimes short and condescending.

I took Several classes from Dr. G when I was an undergrad and grad student.  He is an excellent professor who knows his stuff but you have to put forth the effort and think for yourself;  you will not be spoon fed. Best prof. I have ever had at Ohio State. Took history of WW2 and wish I could take it again. Grade essentially consists of 3 exams (15%, 30%, and 50% of grade respectively. He is a true expert. Exams are pick what you want, for instance pick 1 of 6 essays.  I caution because I love WW2 history and if you have no background this class will be tough

One of the smartest professors I've had here. Learned a lot about the political/military/cultural part of the Vietnam war, and his tests were pick 4 of 12 short answer, etc. so you could focus on what interested you. He was slightly disorganized, but if you attend class/guest lecturers you will be fine. Definitely recommend this class!!
Please stay away from this class ... Just stay away

This is easily the worst teacher I've ever had in my formal education.  His lectures and lecture notes are unorganized, his exams test on things that were never discussed in class, and the TAs were two of the most condescending people I've ever met. Stay as far away from this class as you can.

Deplorable class. Nice man & respect his 2 silvestars, but, it is time for him to hang up the coat & enjoy life - to be respectful. I did NOT get anything from this class - NOTHING. I learned more from The History Ch & Wiki than him. This was suppose to be a Vietnam War class - we barely touched the war. AVOID THIS CLASS & PROF!

AVOID CLASS AT ALL COST Impossible to study for half the stuff on the tests are not in his workbook and his lectures are pointless because he just reads his note without elaborating then expects you to write a page essay about it.  I would avoid this class unless you already know a great deal about not only the Vietnam war but the entire  history.

Dr. Guilmartin is indeed an authority on military knowhow, but unless you are a history major or only interested in the military standpoint of the Vietnam War, please do not take this class.  I love history, but this class holds absolutely no valueable information for you to gain if you aren't in the marines or a major.  DONT TAKE AS A GEC!

Dr. Guilmartin was a fantastic lecturer who is clearly an authority on military history. With that said, he is a bit disorganized and his lecture notes are not always up to date or relevant for his lectures.

Word of warning: the class was completely unstructured. Prof couldn't stick to syllabus, and was all over the place. Literally no one took notes by the end of the quarter bc it was impossible. He goes into tons of details and tangents and the powerpoint is useless. Had to rely on book, wikipedia and memorizing facts to pass this class.
I really enjoyed the content of this class, but the tests were pretty wretched.  ABSOLUTELY go see the TA's!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  That got me through the class!!!!

If you aren't interested in military type things-don't take this class. He teaches it completely military based. There is no useful guidance for the exams which are difficult. He wrote the textbook which is in shorthand notes that dont make sense if you dont already know stuff abt this topic. Basically taught myself thru google. Disappointment.

Simply the finest professor I ever had in eight years of college at four different institutions (including study abroad and grad school).  He's military, you're going to get military thinking from this guy.  The insights are priceless.

Expert and knowledgeable.  Interesting explanations about importance of certain countries' aircraft in World War II. Awful. He is so unprofessional. I can't believe he teaches at OSU. His lectures are awful and half the time he is injecting his political views (right-wing conservative). If you do not like military-type things, do not take this course. Sometimes I felt as though I were in classroom at West Point. The powerpoint presentations and the book, his collection of slides, for the course are worthless. Half of the class used wikipedia prior to exams.

Very sweet old man who just happens to be one of the worst professors I have ever had.  His powerpoints are confusing and his lectures are boring and self-indulgent.  I learned more from the 9 books on Vietnam I checked out of the public library than anything associated with this class.  Plus, he likes to quote himself.
I took the class to to as an elective for my major and was surprised . He is one of the best professors I have ever had. He is not P.C and brought in good guest speakers.

I love WWII history and really looked forward to this class.  Unfortunately, this class was nothing like I expected.  Dr. Guilmartin taught the class from the militaristic point of view.  If artillery, battle tactics, ect aren't your thing DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!  Also, lectures are pointless--he digresses into random stories that don't help at all

Here's the deal: if you like military history, or just history, you can't go wrong with Dr. G. If you hate history or don't like having to go to class, then you'll have problems. He can be unorganized and his lecture notes are somewhat out of date. His tests aren't typical and there is a lot of material. That said, he's great. Give him a chance!

Fantastic Professor!  He is such a sweetie!  His lecture notes are given in a book, and they REALLY need to be updated, but if you pay attention, there are only a few times you extra times you need to write things in. Fantastic Professor!  He is such a sweetie! For and ex-military man he should be ashamed of himself for how unorganised his class is. His exams are unfair, study guides are worthless, and his class is not worth the money you pay.

Always willing to help students.  I took the online version and only had to log onto Carmen four times and I still aced the class.  People dropped out saying it was hard; I have no idea why.  SO easy if you know anything about writing essays.

No guidance or structure really. We were given written lectures and tested four times. The discussion forum was for soldiers and their wives to encourage the Iraq war. The lectures were unreasonably boring. Luckily, reading the lectures and texts didn't seem necessary to a good grade. If I cared about Vietnam, I probably would've liked the class.

I took the on line class, it was a piece of cake, never read the book just printed off his notes for the tests, which was enough to A the tests. I wouldn't take it in person though, would be boring

real cool, kept everything interesting and was real easy to talk to
Very boring lectures, outdated course packet, and terrible slides.  The exams are unnecessarily complicated.  I learned more about the Vietnam War just from reading books on my own time.

Avoid like the plague! Boring lectures, obsecure test questions, and tries to tell horrible jokes.  Workbook hasn't been updated in what looks like 10+ years and his TA's (in my case) just seemed like they didn't want to be bothered with questions.   Unless you MUST take him, STAY AWAY!

He is probably the most boring man alive.  His lectures have nearly no structure.  If you take him in this second level history there is no reason to go to class. Really bad jokes, tells them over and over again, and always screws up the punch lines.

Online format is a little messy, but Dr. G has great insight, is active in the discussion, and has intimate knowledge of the material. His required and optional readings are all great. It would be hard not to learn or do well in this class.
Great prof. Good lectures, fair exams, one of my favorites.

His online class was so unorganized that it was impossible to know when to turn assignments in, the best was when he posted the material the same day as the midterm so we had no chance to study for it!

Great for military historians!
Definitely knows his subject, but not a great lecturer. Hard to hear him in lecture hall setting, relies too heavily on outdated course packets that are hard to read.

He was my advisor and I took 6 classes with him. He is very animated, intelligent, and lets you learn what you value. He is very respectful of students and encourages class participation. The map questions rule! If you make the effort, it will be rewarded

fantastic teacher who is open to new ideas and listens to his students. would recommend him to anyone. i learned much more than just about vietnam during this class. i took away lessons about life and people.
Great Prof.  Would highly reccomnend  no b/s pc in his lectures either, he tells things how they are.

guy fought in vietnam and the lectures are really interesting, if you do take the class, the key is to pick maybe 10 different things from the packets and know those real well, dont try to know everything, just know a few things really well

Best proffesor I have had at OSU, great

Excellent Prof!  Next Sec of Defense!
One of best profs I have had. Very animated and knowledgable
i literally can't imagine having a better teacher for this course
Smart.  Knowledgeable.  Doesn't always know everything, however.  Doesn't like being corrected.  Expert, however.  Teaches good and clear writing and historic descriptions.

Super smart and loves the content she teaches. There are no Power Points so skipping class is very much not recommended. 3 book discussions say one thing and you get full credit. Doesn't use carmen at all so you won't know your grade until the end, but she doesn't really grade that hard. Overall good class and prof would recommend.

NOTE: History 2001H
Old school. Doesn't use Carmen at all, and the lectures are just her talking. This class was interesting, though, and a good light workload for an Honors GE. Besides a few in-class responses and discussions, most of your grade rests on the final, which was very straightforward. She also gives a thorough study guide for it.

Dr. Cashin was very patient and kind. There was a lot of reading to do, and she asks for a paragraph on each thing you've read. The essays you wrote weren't graded too harshly, and she gives you clear ideas of what to fix. The class is discussion based, so she doesn't teach that much but it works very well. Just come to class and do the reading!

She doesnt really teach, its discussions between you and your classmates. Shes more likely the moderator in the situation. That being said, shes one of the most understanding professors Ive had. Shell give you extended time for your work, she helps you out in any way so you understand the material. You wont use Canvas or know your grade.

Professor Cashin fails in every possible category when it comes to teaching. Rather than lecture, she relies entirely on readings and class discussions to "teach." Also, if she doesn't like you, you will not get better than a B. She seems to randomly pick who she likes and hates, and grades are subjective, so your grade rests solely on her mood.

Dr. Cashin is extremely knowledgable about American History in the 19th century and so her lectures are very interesting. If you come to class and read the three books she assigns, its is very easy to get an A. I am looking to take other classes from her in the future!

She is a more old school teacher. Very knowledgable on her subject, and she is really into writings. Lots of the grades you receive will be pass or fail, and the grades are never uploaded on carmen. If you skip class you will be screwed. Like majorly.

Joan is one of the most passionate professors I've had, so her lectures are very interesting. She takes attendance every class, so be there ON TIME. Her three short papers are easy--just read the book, write the paper, and participate, and you'll get full credit. Write down everything she says! The more you write on your final exam, the better.
Joan was brilliant. Her lectures were very interesting and as long as you show up and listen you should easily get an A. Very few assignments but all easy. I would be sure to take her classes again!

Prof Cashin is amazingly knowledgeable about her subject, and if you like American History then you should take her classes. No powerpoints, but taking notes is easy if you pay attention. Small discussions where you show up and say one thing. 3 books to read. Enjoyable and relatively easy, Prof Cashin is very likeable.

She is.... old school. Be ready to show up. Be ready to get called on if your eyes wander. No online material. The books you read are the type you can order on Amazon from goodwill  for 99. Which is nice. But also indicative of the dated material. She seemed nice enough. This is definitely not a show-up-and-pass course. Tests & seminars are TOUGH.

If you are serious about history, specifically Antebellum American and the Civil War, then take her classes and you will not be disappointed.  She is incredibly knowledgeable and well read.  You must go to class, she takes attendance everyday.   A really easy grader as long as you do the work. I take her every semester I can, she's great.

No actual textbooks, but 3 book discussions that are pretty easy. 3 short writing assignments that are passfail, 8-10 page paper, and a final which she gives you a study guide for. Pretty easy grader. Lectures can be somewhat dry sometimes, but overall I really liked her.

The easiest class I've taken in my life. The definition of an easy A. Take somewhat good notes and you'll pass.  Your grade consists of:  Couple group discussions (say one thing), attendance, like 5 one page papers, and a final (you write a paragraph explaining each key termeventperson).  She will give you a long study guide for the final.

Joan is a very oldschool professor. She's cool though, very knowledgeable. She expects you to attend every class. There are 3 book discussions, a final paper, and a final exam. Each is worth 20% of your grade. Show up to class, say one thing in the discussions, do the paper and study the guide for the final and you will probably get an A. Easy

As a Harvard graduate and student of David Donald Herbert, Dr. Cashin provides students with an unparalleled depth of knowledge. I am truly lucky to have had her as a Professor. If you are a serious historian then take her course. She is lenient on assignments and gives students many chances. If you do the readings and show up you should do well.

As others mentioned, she does kind of drone on. If you're interested in history, it's great, but she says a lot of stuff you won't ever see on a midterm or final. I probably only ended up using a third of my notes to study because most of it wasn't on the study guide. The midterm and final were supeeer easy, though, as long as you study the guide.

Dr. Cashin knows her Civil War history.  If you show up and listen during class, you will find yourself very knowledgeable about the subject.  There are three book discussions, and you have to find five primary documents and write five one-page papers about why they are interesting.  This was the easiest class ever, but I enjoyed it.
Boring class, but very easy

She has a tendency to drone and the lack of visual aid makes it harder.  She also gives you a lot of info that you won't need for the final, but it is interesting if you like the subject.  It was very easy, however, so all in all a good class to take
Might look a crazy person though if you attend every class and if you talk during the discussions you should get an A   best history teacher I've had

Had no sympathy for my medical situation that prevented me from attending class regularly.  Violated every right of medical privacy, saying that she had to know in order for me to pass.  At one point, she told me (verbatim) that "the grading system put forth on the syllabus was arbitrary and was changed when the situation deemed necessary".

INsanely boring... especially for an 830 class... she is knowlegable but tends to ramble on and on with no visual aids so you end up writing down an insane amount of stuff you dont need... the structure of the class is easy but attendance is mandatory... good luck not falling asleep!

Very knowledgeable about women in the Civil War; not so much on general CW history. Described the Monitor as a "prototype submarine." Became resolute when a student tried to correct her. Described the  Homer painting "Prisoners from the Front" as a scene showing 5 Southern prisoners, when 2 are clearly Union guards. Doesn't like to be corrected.

Took 557.02 with her, she is incredibly knowledgeable, she spoke essentially nonstop the whole two hours, full of fun tidbits of history that you don't usually get to learn. Also, this is the first 8:30 am class I've yet had where I wasn't pissed at having to go to, I actually looked forward to going to an 8:30am class??? What's happened to me?
The class is incredibly easy (3 book discussions, a paper and a essay). She can be helpful, but can come off as arrogant at times.
Awesome prof!  Really knows what she is talking about, is straight forward with what she expects.  Minimal work.
Very smart, knows what she is talking about. Lectures are actually somewhat interesting.  Midterms are super easy if you go to lecture.  Fair and nice.
Minimal work, extremely easy, a very easy A.  She is also very nice and pleasant.  Highly recommended.
very clear on her expectations, very easy for an honors class. minimal work. tests are ridiculously easy!
Class is very easy IF YOU GO TO CLASS. If you don't go you will FAIL no matter how much you know about the Civil War because your grade is entirly subjective to what she feels like giving you.
Great Prof. Tells you up front what she wants. Requires minimum work and as long as you prepare for the midterm and final you will be set.

very easy. class is all notes and then 3 discussions about the books read. discussions are easy points, just say one thing and you will get full credit. exams are easy as well. she is very fair and interested in teaching; you will learn a lot, but go to class!

Of all the History courses I've taken, I would have to say she provides the best info about her area...you will know more than you ever thought there was to know about the Civil War.  Go to class, take notes and you will get a good grade.

Unfair, contentious, and seriously vindictive.  Expressing contrary opinions is a sure way to fail the class.  All 398 classes are based on an extremely subjective grading system: class discussion and a paper.  Thus, the student is literally at the mercy of the professor.  Stay away from this one.

Very very very well versed on the Civil War, and accepts input from everyone. Not too great at mediating arguments, but those were rare anyhow. Still, very helpful and smart. I think her style is well suited for a discussion class.
She is the best.  She made the class so interesting.  You will work hard, but if you earn a good grade you will have deserved it.  Take all her classes.
Good for a small group in a discussion class.
The best at what she does.  559 was great.  I also had her in 557.03.  Looking forward to having her this coming spring for 598.01.

What can I say?  Prof. Joan Cashin is the best.  A Harvard graduate, she really knows her stuff.  She can challenge any male professor on Civil War history, and probably win the argument.  Joan rocks!!!
History of Slavery.  Fun & enjoyable.  Explained lots of little known things to shatter the stereotypes.  Humane professor and not too mean or vindictive.   9/10
History of Slavery.  Very good.  Excellent professor.  Explained a lot of unknown facts.  Really helpful to our understanding of this subject matter.
No Comments
I'd never taken a history class before and got an A.  As long as you say one thing in the book discussion that counts for 60% of your grade.  Very easy and very smart.

She is Civil War expert.  Knows all the inside stories, & tries to make lectures interesting.  Final grade will help, however.  Adds little known tabloid gossip about famous Civil War people, to make class a little more fun.  Nice person.
this was my final quarter, and this class was the best class i've ever had.  the teacher made the already interesting material even more interesting and extraordinarily accessible.
No Comments
What a waste of time.  I have heard that she is unable to teach grad students because of her mean personality.  I loved the civil war, not the class
She plays favorites, and those that she likes, she is very nice to...Those that she doesn't like or doesn't know, she is very snotty towards.
No Comments
Cranky.  Whining.  Yes, obsessed with Catherine the Great.  Maybe he wanted to be the horse, lol.

A very caring professor who gives clear lectures and is very willing to answer any questions. His slides are pretty sparse though so note taking is recommended. He gives a lot of feedback on papers. Although some days had a lot of reading, he suggested just picking just one detail to share if there was a discussion, so it was low pressure.
Lectures are not mandatory but the discussion once a week is and you need to participate.

Professor Breyfogle is a very passionate lecturer, and uses this energy to clearly communicate the information to the class, and maintains the interest and attention of his students throughout the entire lecture. This was my favorite class this semester, and I would definitely recommend this professor!

He is very passionate about what he talks about. He is also very fair when it comes to expectations about assignments. Everything is clearly laid out on the syllabus. A warning though, even though lectures is not mandatory, the material in them will be crucial to meet the word requirements in the Final Exam so listen and take good notes!

Good dude, he makes it a really interesting class. The papers are hard and its graded really tough but you can get up to 10% of extra credit and the discussion section of the class is worth 30% of your grade so if you read and participate you'll get a good grade even if you don't do too hot on the papers.

The History of Water was one of my favorite classes I have every taken. Very interesting and unique. You write a paper every 2 weeks or so, but you have to read every week before discussion. Overall great class, not too much work

One of the better professors I've had, he is very devoted and passionate about the course material and gives interesting lectures, definitely learned a lot. Lectures are skippable but you must attend recitation every week.  Tests are all short answers and essay also a paper, managed an A without doing a ton of work & completing all extra credit

Breyfogle is a wonderful lecturer. He has lots and lots of reading. I'm a history major, and his class was maybe the most reading I've ever had. Lots of essays. He gave great feedback, but he expects a lot.

One of the best history professors I have had at OSU. The class subject matter is very interesting and Breyfogle makes it fun with clear and enthusiastic lectures. Discussion days as well. Class very paper heavy (determines most of your grade) and relies on the assigned novels. However, Dr. Breyfogle is very accessible and reads drafts beforehand

GREAT! Take his class, I took his Modern European history, great class and easiest A I have ever gotten. He offers 10% of final grade in extra credit (max score in class could be 110%) very easy, but very interesting. Great! Take it!

Professor Breyfogle was my favorite professor and I found a new interest in European history because of his enthusiastic lectures. He makes the class exciting and he is interested in the material. Study guides are terms that will be selected from for the tests, preparation is all you need for an A. Would HIGHLY recommend. Attendance is important

Prof Breyfogle made this class SO interesting because of his passion. He made this class so enjoyable. You HAVE to participate in recitation or you won't get a good grade. He hands out all the questions to the exams, which are short answers and essays, before hand so if you prepare well you'll do well. The books we had to read were interesting.

Amazing professor. Took 2204 as a gen ed and ended up loving the class because of Professor Breyfogle. Very educated on course matter and does more than read off slides. Doesn't put anything online so you have to attend class, but you'll be glad you did. Gives extra credit and easy to follow study guides for exams. Participate and you'll get an A

Professor Breyfogle is a great teacher.  I hate history and he actually makes the lectures interesting and fun.  He does not put lecture notes online so you have to go to lecture and listen, but he's so animated and passionate about history that it's nice to listen to.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. His lectures are very interesting and well organized and his sense of humor is great. He's always more than happy to talk after class too. He is a bit of a tough grader and the tests aren't exactly easy. You'll have a ton of reading too and if you don't do it you're screwed. I give this class 8.5/10

Prof. Breyfogle is awesome! His lectures are engaging, his sense of humor keeps things fun, and he moves through the material at a good pace. He is very clear about what he expects on tests and hands out the questions ahead of time. The reading assignments are really long, though, and he can be a tough grader at times. You have to work for it a bit

Prof. Breyfogle is a great instructor, his lectures are very engaging. The downside of this class was the huge amount of readings required how hard essays are graded. I spent twice as much time studying for this class and I didn't get the grade I expected. I don't recommend taking it if you have more than 12 credits.

Dr. Breyfogle was the best professor I have had at OSU. The lectures were always well organized and very interesting. He does expect a lot from you but the knowledge I gained made it very worth while. Great man, great class you should take it.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. Has a sense of humor, easy to approach. He takes the time to answer any questions and loves to talk after lecture. He even recognized me and said hello when I saw him at the library and I'd only talked to him once after lecture. His class WILL be demanding but he's more than happy to help.

Chances are that you're thinking about taking Professor Breyfogle's class. DO IT! He is a great professor that cares about the improvement of his students beyond the class...by far the best professor and class I've had. Very engaging and makes the material exciting! I highly recommend him to anyone!

This class so far was the best one I ever took in OSU. Of course the class is not easy and you do need some background on what is being covered here but if you do all the readings and attend lecture, you should be fine. The TA that I had for recietation had a good knowledge on what is being said and very helpful on helping students

He's hard...no lie!  You don't have to go lecture as long as u read the book.  He gives you the test ?s before hand...he's not tricky, he tells you EXACTLY what he expects.  He expects a lot, though.  His TA's are tough, but nice.  Overall he's great, but if you are not willing to work, then you will hate it.

He's a pretty good teacher who gives very interesting lectures.  He expects students to read way too much though (25-35 pages of textbook a night on average) for a GEC class.  Overall a good teacher, just needs to tone down the readings.
Anyone else notice he sounds like Steve Colbert from the Daily Show?  It makes for interesting Lectures.
A nice enough fellow, but his lectures were all over the place - too many insignificant details, he forgot the bigger picture.
Very interested in teaching. Clear studying instructions for the exams and readings. Grades also depend on TAs who seem to be fair.
Great teacher, made me enjoy going to a class that I usually would have slept through. Not hard to look at either.
Great Professor - well worth your time.

Possibly the best prof I've had down here. He's very intelligent, very entertaining, and yes, very down to earth. Anyone that thinks he's arrogant has obviously never spoken to the man. He is very down to earth, and he answers every question asked in lecture.
Excellent!  I thought he was wonderful- kept discussions moving, always available.  But tough and demanding!  Definitely top notch, even if grades on papers not completely clear.

I enjoy Dr. Breyfogle's lectures ENORMOUSLY! Having Jaimie Sassone for discussion, however, is comparable to the ebola virus, except that the symptoms of diarrhea, vomiting, and extensive bleeding, though acute, will cease by the end of the quarter.

This guy seems to think his class will change the world. He has a lot of energy, which is good I suppose. I just took my first midterm, it was pretty easy. He gave us the questions that were going to be on it a week in advance.  Lectures aren't TOO boring
Talks to fast.  Too loud.  Expects way too much.  Too much emphasis on sex life of Catherine the Great.  Maybe he wishes he was alive at that time.  LOL & LMAO !!!!!
Rude.  Arrogant.  Just plain mean.  All of the above.  Plus obnoxious.  Plus too loud & screaming all the lectures.  (Please:  it was not that big of a room, for crying out loud!!)
No Comments
terrible; has pets; ignores certain people who raise their hands with comments; poor rapport; is very hard to get along with
excellent professor, great personality
big ego, but very helpful.  very demanding and sometimes not realistic
Very excellent.  Knows the era.  Interested in students.  Good lectures.  Clear objectives.
Very nice.  Very competent and capable.

If u are a decent/good writer, you'll be fine. Lectures r long, can be interesting if u like pres elections. Doesn't have clear grading criteria, just ask & she grades pretty easily.  Very knowledgeable and cares about what she teaches. Ur grade will reflect wht u put into this class. As long as u put in a little time & effort, you'll be fine.

Super long, boring lectures that you have to pay attention to the whole time to get a decent grade. When you submit assignments she just responds with rhetorical questions, leaving you to feel like you always could have done better, even if you got a decent grade.

A really nice lady, and she does well in making sure you actually learn the content, instead of just having you memorize information, having you apply your knowledge to papers. With that being said, most of the course revolves around papers, and the quizzes were 60% extended response. The workload was small, but revolves around the papers.

Prof Baker is a good choice for a history class. I didn't know much about the Gilded Era going in, but knew a lot more coming out. Not overly hard classwork, but it can take some time. Pay attention in class and it's super easy to do the work.

Lots of papers but Professor Baker grades them leniently. MC quizzes are tough and reference readings which are dense and otherwise not necessary, but the short answer part makes up for it. Lectures are boring even if you are interested in Presidential History. She does um a lot but I didnt find it too distracting.
Her style isn't for everyone maybe, ask the right question and her answers were always very good.

Quizzes were multiple choice/short answer, but exams were all essays and she also assigned an essay, so this was fairly stressful. Lots of reading/books, some more important than others. She's great, and I got her sense of humor, but man was the class dull sometimes. Overall not hard to get an A, but not easy either.

Do the reading and go to class for sure she takes attendance. Don't try to answer with any original though or she will grade it tough. Just regurgitate her own opinions and you'll get a good grade. Very few grades so everythings weighted pretty heavily.
Nice lady.

Her lectures mostly consist of her rambling. Pretty much nothing happened in the Gilded Age and Progressive Era, so maybe that has something to do with how boring the lectures were. Overall, she was nice and seemed to want her students to do well. She grades fairly but the TA for this class graded much harder.

Prof. Baker knows the material very well but promotes class discussion more than lecturing.  Exams were essay-based and were always about things which were discussed for at least an hour in class.  If you are looking for a good history class with an easy A, go with Prof. Baker.

Interesting content, but her lectures are fairly dry. She uses "umm" a lot. Not a difficult class, assignment-wise. 5% attendance. Have to read a couple novels for the tests, which are short and succinct. Only 1 paper; graded fairly easily.
Says "Um" and "Uh" a lot.  Class was very dull

Took 564 and 566 with her.  She doesn't say 'um' anymore, but her lectures can be rather dry.  However, she knows her stuff and lets you know her expectations on all assignments.  She has review sessions for the exams where she goes over the possible exam questions one by one.  Exams are normally essay based but not too specific.

Overall, it was an easy A. In addition, I learned a lot about the Gilded Age and the Progressive Era. She only makes you write one, 5 page paper! Paper topics were bad but I still got a 100% (Just make sure you put effort into it). She doesn't really say "um" anymore so don't count that against her. Take her if you want to learn A LOT and get an A.
Paula Baker is a good scholar, a thoughtful teacher, and one of the most decent people I have met in the historical racket.

Baker is knowledgeable, interesting, helpful, and funny. Her lecture style takes some getting used to as she pauses a lot, asks leading questions, and goes onto tangents, but none of that negates the quality of the class.

Very knowledgeable professor.  Well organized, and knows her subject area.  The Titanic part of the final lecture was a chiller, one of the many unfortunate events that occurred on the eve of World War One.  All in all, this was a very interesting class (Gilded Age to Progressive Era), and I would recommend it to people who wish to study that era.

This woman could not teach her way out of a paper bag. Lectures were rambling, theme-less, and poorly delivered. She frequently wasted class time with pointless group discussions. Readings were coma-inducing. Take someone else.
Lectures were sometimes boring, but I liked that she used videos and old commercials and media, it made things more interesting.  Fairly easy class, very easy if you actually do all of the reading.
The class is not very difficult (she gives easy quizzes/study guides), but it is incredibly boring. Relies far too much on videos! She was either hit or miss on her lectures
Worked with me and was critical to helping me find direction in graduate school and research.
Lectures are ok. Very helpful, but had to write a lot of papers. Hard grader on the papers. Really knows what she is talking about.
Easy grader.  Not very clear in lecture and very scattered, but she does help and clarify whenever you ask.  Recommended.

Yes her lectures are a little dry, but she is damn good at teaching over all.  She is very clear at what she wants, and she grades very easy.  If you come to class, listen, and do what she ask of the studentst to do, you will do fine.
Lectures very boring.  Says "uh" every other time she opens her mouth.  Exams easy though.  Not a very exciting class.  She tries though!
This Prof is willing to help. Tends to let you out of class early which is nice, but her lectures are very unorganized and extremely boring!
Yeah lectures are not the best, but she knows a lot and attempts to convey that knowledge.
Poorly organized, seemed to have no plan for the class. The bright side is she was an easy grader.
This had to be the worst lecture ever. Could not stay awake no matter what, no theme to the class at all. Not to mention the "uh" every other word, that was distracting

Although I agree 100% that this class was boring, unorganized, and hard to follow if you're good at writing essays you'll do fine.  I barely did any of the readings and couldn't pay attention in class if I tried.  The "uh"s were way to distracting.  Between the paper and the two exams though I ended

She's a nice lady, but the class seems to have no direction whatsoever. There's no clear general theme or tone to be derived from the class, so it's all pretty much a mismash of whatever topics she can think of. Not a great way to run a History course.

this may possibly have been the most uninteresting class i have ever taken. with all seriosiness, in the space of 5 minutes the prof said "uh" 97 times. her expections are unclear and i can't seem to get enough caffeine inme to keep me awake for the hour and 48 minutes...beware
Good lectures.  Lots of reading.  Lots of paper writing.  Tough critic when grading papers, but well-meaning.

The only assignments for this class are 3 essays. He is a tough grader which I was intimidated by at first. If you go to his office hours and talk to him about your papers, he will grade them himself (instead of his TA's) and he will give you a much better score since it shows that you cared and put in the extra effort. Extremely nice guy!
Knowledgeable.  Expert.  Writes textbooks.  Interesting insights.

Very boring. Business history is not a fun topic and if you can get away with it, try taking something else. I thought this class would be about the development of business throughout history. Not so much, several isolated examples with less focus on the big piture. emphasis on early Japan, again not fun. Tough grader!!!
Very knowledgeable and interesting.  Kind of tough, but he knows his stuff and genuinely cares about students.  Very good profession in my opinion.
Nice guy, but really hard grader. I've never recieved a C on a paper until this class. He is so knowledgeable that he expects perfection in papers.
really great
His only 2007 comments:  Nice person.  Pretends he is too sophisticated, but deep down he is human and friendly.  A hard grader, but has interesting insights.  9/10

has a great knowledge & passion for class subject matter - uses multiple forms of media such as audio tapes & picture slides - so in love with himself & arrogant it can be hard to watch - taking classes in business before taking this one might be extra helpful - fair grader - watch your grammar/structure in papers - he's a character

Very pleasant professor.  Walking library of information.  He has experienced so much and is a true historian.  Most brilliant professors I have met lack personality/humor/sympathy, but Dr. Blackford is an exception.  What more can I say, a brilliant man with a great personality.

Terrific professor. He clearly loves the material, and has a pretty interesting and relevant personal past associated with it. Not the easiest grader ever, but he's honest and consistent. He's also really personable, and funny as all get out. Take his classes, you won't regret it.
