knowledgable but ignorant. very unprofessional and rude when i try to speak with the TA, he would try and have me stay away and not talk about the tests.he immidiately assumes i didnt read the f-in book.if there are records of identifiying students taking out books from the reserved,they should check it out bc i took out books 2-3 times week.

He was a great prof-very knowledgable-applies history to real life circumstances-uses a variety of teaching tools-video,radio, overheads. A hard grader on papers but will help you if you ask. Definately take him!
For being a Non-Native professor teaching a Native American history class, he was very knowledgeable. He was really nice, and for an upper-division class, it was very fun.
No Comments

Well, I thought Mansel was a pretty neat guy. I stopped by his office hours one time and talked about his Japan travels, which was totally awesome to me, as I am love travel. Very intelligent man, would recommend his classes to all, cute Indiana Jones hat ;)

Wasn't thrilled at having to take a history class, but it was fascinating. I took classes from him in the 80's, have found the knowledge useful many times since-it gives you a perpective from which to analyze business past and present.  The comparative class has been useful too.  Highly recommended!
No Comments
Fascinating guy.  Kinda sexy, for older man.  Don't tell him I said so.  Tries his best at humor.  Showed us pic of when he was 20 year old college student.  Hilarious!
Helpful.  Charming at times.  Witty & urbane.  Publishes many books.  Expert at business history.  Twinkle in eye.  A great listener to sob stories.  Very nice person, lol.
Very laid-back prof. Approachable, very knowledgable. Class was 4 short papers, no exams, which was a plus. Alot of reading, though. One of OSU's best...

I love this guy!   he's an older man who presents his material great....  he has expirienced alot of things right out of history,  and really keeps you interested. i actually liked this class, and he gives you alot of hints for his exams.
Not always friendly.  A little sarcastic.  Not very enthusiastic.

I really enjoyed this class and learned a lot. This isn't your euro-centric AP history course, instead it is a well-through history class that encompasses a comprehensive history of America. You should def take her class if you want to truly learn about American history.
Excellent teacher. You should def. take her! You'll learn a lot about American history. This isn't your Euro-centric AP History crap.
She is awesome

I took Ms. Wu's Women's Studies: The American Woman's Movement. We read a book a week and then talked about it in student led discussions.  It was very interesting and I learned a lot, but it was a lot of work.  Also, since we only really met once a week, attendance was mandatory.  She had lots of extra credit opportunities.
Great professor, knowledgeable, and very helpful. Really enjoyed her class and the final project.
No Comments
I liked her, she made the class interesting and made us work together. Plus there was hot girls in the class so it made it more fun!
Powerpoint notes could have been better, but assigned readings were very interesting. Just be prepared to write alot. Good Prof all and all.
I think she's fabulous!  Very bright, helpful, assigns interesting texts, and understanding if you have a problem.  She really loves teaching, leads discussions well and is so nice.

The amount of reading for this class is extremely heavy, to the point of being unreasonable.  Prof tries to fit too much in too little time.  TA is the only one who does grading.  Loved the subject but the teaching style made it hard to enjoy.

Teacher overloads students with readings. Very unclear, when we go over readings she only replies " thats one way to look at it." Is there no correct answer?  There is when the angry TA grades papers and quizes, TA is grading with a vengence.  And only looks for her answers. Out of sync these 2 are.

Dry.  Boring.  Worked us way too hard.  Way too much trivia.  Interesting class, though.  TA was pretty well organized; I was impressed.  Not many professors get TAs to work with them.  Glad too see lots of guys in class, besides women.

Extremely nice professor, tries to interact with the class. Asian American history was a good course. Lectures were a little boring at times, but some topics were interesting. Midterm was easy (short answer & essay), and we had a final project (no exam)!
Very nice person, patient and learns everyones name.  Talks the entire two hours with no break, but is interesting and well educated in her field.
Teaches interesting classes.  Taught a class on social movements in the 60's and Asian American Women's History.  I learned a lot in both classes.  Take any class she teaches!
American Women's History.  Too much information overload.  Dry & almost humorless.  Nice person underneath it all.  Interesting final projects.  Good rapport in TA classes.

You should be ready to attend as many classes as possible as she does grade for attendance. We did not have many assignments, but she was understanding on the in-class assignments if you had an excused absence. I would recommend her to anyone looking to take this class.

Professor Soland's class is very interesting and she is kind. I really enjoyed the unique content regarding women and the Holocaust. The only negative thing about this class is the little amount of assignments, and how late she grades them. I would recommend doing the extra credit, even if you do not think you need it at the moment.
The class was really interesting and she was very engaging. The material basically framed the holocaust through a female specific lens, which I found very interesting. Would take again!

Prof. Soland is super knowledgeable and passionate. AUT23 was the first time this class was taught, so there were a few kinks to work out but overall, it was pretty good. That being said, she is a huge stickler about participation, but show up to class, do the readings, and discuss your opinion with her and your peers and you'll be fine.

Professor Soland is an extremely educated and caring person. If you struggle AT ALL, she will give you second chances, just don't shy away from asking her. She is incredibly understanding as long as you show an interest in what she is teaching. It's nearly impossible not to develop interest due to how engaging the material is within her class.

I had her for a seminar, so it was completely discussion based, and participation is graded. Her grading is a little difficult to predict, but in general it wasn't bad. There's a lot of readings, at least 3 lengthy articles a week, with 1 page papers due each week about the readings.

She gave us a Nazi sympathizer website to use as an academic resource. My class brought this to her attention, she said "I've never noticed that before." She also said that Belgium wasn't involved in World War 1. Couldn't pay me to take her class again.

Really easy class, it's only four papers. I wrote all of them in 30 minutes and got As. She's nice but can be a little confusing. She did have us write a paper using a website that was created by the daughter of a Nazi and the website was almost in honor of the mom so that was really weird.

I honestly don't understand all the negative feedback. Professor Søland was one of the kindest and most understanding professors I've ever had. There isn't that much required reading and she posts all readings on carmen. Discussion matters but her class is so engaging it's easy to participate. Overall, amazing professor.

I was surprised to see such low ratings for Professor Søland. She is light hearted and although shes a tough grader, she offers many extra credit assignments and very little homework. If youre looking for a relatively easy GE that covers two areas of study, History 2275 is the way to go.
Very harsh grader--doesn't curve. Participation is mandatory and is graded very highly.

I had her for History of Children and Childhood. Some of the information presented was interesting and thought provoking but most of it was not. Her grading was very unclear. Participation in class was a big part of your grade but she wasn't clear on how she keeps track/ counts the people that speak. Essays were graded fairly and no exams.

She was the worst teacher I have had in 15 years of schooling. She was not clear with what she wanted, graded insanely harshly, and would blame the class for her own mistakes. She put up "bad" responses of midterm questions in class and had us say what was wrong, without the permission of the authors of the answers (who were sitting in the class).

Some of my classmates had really bad interactions with her in and outside of class. She took points off for really random things on essays and exams and it was really unclear sometimes what she was looking for. No textbook so if you don't go to class, you're out of luck. I would avoid this class if you can.

First, just go. I had a hard time attending her class and it hurt me bad. Her grading system is a mess. She freaked out on our class a few times for her mistakes. Her class depends on what kind of student you are. If you like to speak often then you will enjoy her. If you are the kind of person who likes to listen, probably not for you. She's nice.

Grading is all over.  She said participation mattered, but many students spoke nearly every single day in class and still didn't pull full points on participation, so whatever she is looking for is unclear.  I typically get A's and am lucky to get out of here with a decent grade.  All grades were group projects, you WILL have to do extra credit.

Grading was very unclear, she only put one grade in for the semester and it ended up being my final grade. Participation is huge, I think there were 4 papers and participation that went towards the final grade. The class was not as interesting as I anticipated but professor soland was pretty passionate and very knowledgeable.

Took this as a May session class and it was very easy. No tests, just a group project every week and a final paper but she is pretty easy on grading. A big chunk of your grade is participation so be ready to talk during class. Overall good class and Dr. Soland was very nice and helpful.

Do not take her class. She is a controlling professor who is not helpful. Her grading makes NO SENSE and she takes her gen ed class so seriously its not worth your time. Also just boring material in general.

History 1152. Prof. Kraemer is insanely passionate about history and a great teacher. Hardly uses notes and can talk about anything. Extremely willing to work with students. Very nice ec offered. Attendance is mandatory. Extremely transparent on grading. Wants everyone to thrive. Couldn't recommend this class more!

Professor Kraemer is extremely nice and is very passionate about the class. (Intro to Native American history). The class was fun, but there were not a lot of assignments so do not miss them. Attendance mandatory but he is good about working with you to accommodate.

Took HIS 222 at SNHU from this professor and honestly do not recommend it. He expects you to go above and beyond the requirements on the rubrics and always has to dock points. Tons of pointless reading and just overall boring. He does do good at giving (sometimes pointless) feedback though.

I had the pleasure of taking his War and Society before 1800 at SNHU, and I enjoyed the class. However, he does require a lot of reading and writing. He was available and ready to assist in any way he could. I don't have any real complaints, but at the same time I don't have many praises either. Good teacher but could have been better.
Honestly probably the worst Professor I ever had. Please do yourself a favor and never take Clemm.

It is an essay based class, but Clemm really does reward thoughtful effort regardless of if you're 100% correct. Don't take 112 if you don't like writing essays. A reasonable amount of effort will get you a good grade in the course, and Clemm is willing to help if you ask for it early enough before the due date of an essay.

He takes himself way too seriously to be teaching a 100-lvl hist course ONLINE. He asks general opinionated questions like "Why is so-and-so important?" and if your answer isn't what HE thinks it should be (i.e. he doesn't feel your reason was important) he won't give you any credit.
DONT EVER TAKE A CLASS THIS THIS TEACHER!!!!

Two things robert does that you will not see with other professors, both of which are outlined on his syllabus making them "law." 1. He does not answer any emails on the weekend  2. He does not accept any late work (even if its barely late and worth 15% of your grade). Hes a young teacher trying to show he is boss but he has no phd. Not recommended
he assigns way too many essays

Professor Dragostinova is great! The class is almost all lectures but it is very interesting and engaging. She manages to make one of the most complex periods of history digestible and entertaining. You can tell she is passionate about what she teaches. If you go to class and engage in the readings, you should be fine in the course.

Nice professor, but her grading criteria are extraordinary, her discussion posts don't make any sense and then when you try to give some form of answer, she tells you to go to the Writing Center. if the assignment does not make any sense and all the students are confused about it, they might as well just do book report assignments then.

Engaging, passionate, and friendly professor. Post-WWII European History is a complicated and fascinating area that I knew nothing about! Grading is a little strange, she isn't particularly harsh but rarely gives grades above 95 and almost never above 98. There's a midterm and final paper, and a bunch of reflection papers (6 required, 10 assigned)

This class was alright I guess. The grading criteria were not clear at all, and you get docked points for the stupidest things. Also, the lectures are so boring, I have taken European History classes multiple times, and this is the worst one.

Despite my loathing of a majority of the material, I genuinely enjoyed this class and felt that I had actually learned a lot by the end of the semester. Dr. Dragostinova is very smart and likes the material she is teaching, which made the class better overall. To pass, all you should really have to do is watch the lectures and take notes!
Don't take this class for an easy elective. Nit-picky grader over small stuff and requires a lot more effort than a 3 credit elective should in my opinion.

She's a great professor. One map quiz, five response papers, a book review, midterm and final research project. The response papers, book review, and quiz are easy but the midterm was difficult (essay) and she looks for specific answers on the prompts. Make sure you understand what she is looking for in the papers. A LOT of reading, but a fun class

Professor Dragostinova was always energetic and excited to teach. As long as you fill out the outlines for every class you dont need to do the readings as the tests are based on the lecture material. The weekly discussion posts were a big part of the grade, but she does give extra credit opportunities and points for attendance which helps.

Professor Dragostinova is an amazing professor for modern european history. If I had to take another class with her I would. She genuinely cares about the material & loves teaching it & I actually was excited to go to class everyday. She's Bulgarian & has a slight accent but its clear & you know what she is saying at all times and isnt a problem.

Professor Cabanes is by far my favorite professor that I have had so far. He is more than willing to hear other views or respond to any questions. His exams are a large part of the grade but he makes sure you are prepared for them. The other assignments were actually enjoyable because it was either a movie or book. Would definitely recommend.

I enjoyed Mr. Cabanes' class a ton. The lectures were interesting. Homework consisted of watching movies and reading a few books so it wasn't difficult. The class is exam-heavy but the only really difficult ones are the Midterm and the Final, the movie exams aren't very difficult and are very fun to do. I would highly recommend this class!

Cabanes is incredibly kind and the lectures were always interesting as he is very knowledgeable about war. The grader for the course is a little tough and there are only 3 quizzes on movies, a midterm, final, & book essay which meant the weight of things was high. Easy review sessions for midterm and final w TONS of extra credit. Take this class!

Clearly knowledgeable about the material and makes the lectures very interesting. Read several short books and watched films outside of class. Grading based on two exams and a paper along with pop quizzes based on the readings. Fairly easy class and a great professor

Heavy course material but done in a way that is super interesting and really engaging. Professor Cabanes is a great professor, he's clear about themes in the class and emphasizes important concepts over intricate details, which is very refreshing for a history course. It's the first history course I've genuinely enjoyed in while.

The class is extremely interesting to the point I wished the lectures were longer. There is a clear grading criteria and the exams are easy. You have to take detailed notes and pay attention if you want to pass. Not going to lecture and sitting on your phone or computer will dramatically affect your grade. There are pop quizzes on readings.

Bruno was a great professor with detailed notes. His lectures were heavy and detailed, but organized and interesting. He and the TA made sure you were prepared for the exams and finals. Very interesting course.
Pop quizzes, one paper, midterm, final. The lectures are chock-full of information and dry if you aren't that into history. But no doubt you will learn a ton.

History minor, expected an easy A, but you will only get an A if you work reasonably hard. This was his first class taught at OSU, so the material is being pared down a lot, but originally it was a LOT of reading (60 pgsnight).FANTASTIC professor, cool French accent, great focus on EXPERIENCE of war (not military tactics). Interesting lectures!
Excellent, knowledgeable professor who truly cares about his students.

I really liked Professor Brakke because he is clearly knowledgable about what he is teaching. He was always available to talk to outside of class or after class. Papers and exams were graded very fairly. Lots of reading but readings are talked about in class so it's not terrible if you miss a couple. Not easy for an A but not incredibly hard.

Really niche class so if you aren't super into it, choose something else. Cool history overall. Lots of reading. If you bomb the midterm like I did you're basically screwed. Your grade consists of 2 papers, a midterm, and the final. So mess up on any of those and you're toast. Attendance also counts. Overall, not bad. But also kind of boring

very nice guy, very knowledgable about Christianity and the facts behind it, doesn't get super religious or try to convert, merely presents facts. lecture attendance is optional but recitation is mandatory. 3 big papers, not many assignments, want to go to lecture and take notes besides those he posts online. would definitely recommend!

Absolutely terrible. He's obviously very qualified in what he does, insofar as he knows what he teaches, but the fact that this class (HIST 3229) is available for a GE is absolutely absurd, and moreover, he treats it as if each student in the class is a history major. You get 4 grades, no study guides, no reviews. Prepare to suffer if you take this
Prof. Brakke is one of the friendliest profs I've ever had.  Extremely inviting and very helpful if you go to officer hours.

Brakke is an amazing lecturer and makes information, that probably could be boring, super interesting. There's a lot of work in this class, but you learn A TON! If you're interested in Christianity in the slightest, you'll really enjoy this class.

Amazing professor. The class was very interesting--every day felt like story time. The class doesn't require any knowledge of Christianity or its history to be successful in the course. Be prepared for lots of readings.

I agree with the previous statement that the class was graded harshly, especially for a 2000 level class. I enjoyed Dr. Brakke's lectures. Very interesting & funny. Sam (the TA) was also awesome. Very funny and helpful, just a little tough on the grading. I'd recommend only if you're willing to go to every class and if you're a strong writer.
Great guy, but class is graded extremely harsh. Don't recommend it unless you're simply interested in the material and not your grade.
There is a reason he has such a good rating on here. I would highly recommend that anyone needing to fill a history elective take his class.

Brakke is FANTASTIC!!  This class was my favorite by far at Ohio State.  He is so learned in Christian history and we covered so much in lecture.  He was nice, funny, interesting, and kept the class pretty straightforward.  2 midterms, 2 papers, and a final.  Lots of primary source readings, but I didn't really do them.
By far one of the best professors I have had. He made the lectures really interesting, and was very clear about conveying the material. I would highly recommend him.
Professor Esposito was an amazing lecturer and person, very accommodating for all circumstances and class work was straightforward!

Well-organized online class consisting of weekly discussion posts and then a final paper. Dr. Esposito's lectures as well as the readings are informative and interesting. Guidelines are clear and you can choose from multiple essay topics for the final essay.

I loved taking this class this semester. I dropped Spanish and needed another to fill its spot and I'm SO glad that I did. Only graded on 7 assignments which are all discussion boards, final essay topic and guidelines given well in advance, and overall just an interesting class. If you're into anthropology like myself I think you'll enjoy it!
I took Professor Tuxberry-Gleissner's SLAVIC 3320 class as a GENED. It was easy and pretty interesting. I would recommend if you are interested in Eastern European culture, if not you WILL be bored.

Goldish is very knowledgeable and funny but goes on tangents which can be boring, especially in a class where no electronics are allowed. He grades fairly, but if you're not interested in the Salem Witch Trials the coursework can get repetitive.

I found this class pretty easy. As long as you can watch a movie and do a (lowkey pretty long) reading every week, you're solid. His lectures are extremely boring but a of of people just left after taking the weekly quiz (which were easy if you did the hw.) The final test was online and the final paper was pretty fun to write.

Pretty easy GE but expect to read 60-90 pages a week. if you are not willing to read and manage the homework effectively, don't take this class. There is a quiz every week then long lecture afterwards. Paper was super easy, but he graded really strict on the final. He's pretty nice and responds quickly.

You can pour tons of time into taking notes and preparing for one class, but then there's no quiz on it. But the next class where you maybe didn't have time to annotate as much or have to miss for a UNIVERSITY SANCTIONED EVENT you best believe there will be a quiz. He drops two quizzes, but heaven forbid you're involved, there won't be an exception

The professor is so old-fashioned. No lecture material, he did not write anything on the board. It was like listening to a podcast but getting graded on it. The quizzes were on details from the long readings, so you cannot just skim them. Horrible experience. We live in 2023. Learn how to adapt to the times or do not teach.

Professor Goldish is one of a kind!!! His extensive knowledge on history and ability to teach it through a variety of perspectives is really interesting. He is super funny, so staying awake in class is never an issue. There is a movie and reading assignment every week that you get quizzed on, but they are very simple with no tricks :)

Professor Goldish does a wonderful job of making sure the students have to be involved in both the reading and the class by actively engaging in both conversation and the use of pop quizzes. Do not take this class if you are not willing to read outside of class and take decent notes within class. He is also fairly anti-technology, bring paper/pen.

There's a lot of reading, pop quizzes, no lecture slides, and no technology allowed in class w/o an exemption so if that's not your style this course isn't for you. I found the subject matter super interesting and unique and enjoyed Dr. Goldish, he is knowledgeable and passionate about his class. I would recommend to anyone who enjoys niche history

Professor Goldish laid out his expectations clearly in class and in the syllabus and wasn't lying! This is a high level history course, so don't expect to go in and learn spells and watch Hocus Pocus. If you are one that likes PowerPoints to guide your notes, you will not enjoy his lectures. Read his syllabus carefully as it lays out everything.

An average class. Dont expect anything like slides or key topics. If you do the readings, youll be fine, but make sure you take good notes in class. Lectures are not engaging. Not too difficult, just not too interesting either.

This is a HISTORY class, NOT broomsticks and spells. You WILL learn ways people classify religion, science, and technology as magic. The professor expects college level work and does ask you to prepare your own notes. He will not spell out the material for you. Class is based on assigned readings and discussions as well as easy quizzes.

Professor Goldish is awesome! Be prepared for class and show up and it will be rewarding! I am not a history major and took this as a fun history credit with no prior knowledge and was able to succeed in this course. Be sure to actually read the syllabus and understand how the course works before committing to it! Totally recommend for all majors.

Professor Goldish was interesting. He definitely seemed extremely knowledgeable in the subject, but either wanted to show off his intellect or thought he was teaching a higher level class. This course felt like it was incorrectly marked as a GE, but fits a high level history course. Lots of reading and lectures that didn't really apply to the text

Professor Goldish is probably the smartest person I have ever met, and his intellect is comparable to some of the great thinkers of the Scientific Revolution that we learned about in his class. The course was lecture and reading heavy, but his lectures were engaging and informative and I enjoyed every one. The class isn't for the faint of mind.
Prof Goldish was a really nice guy and had very few assignments that weren't that bad. The lectures were a bit boring sometimes when he would go on tangents.

Vehemently excluded Black jewish people from the course content and was argumentative about Black and brown Jewish peoples importance in the community. Centered the entire class around the contributions of white rabbinates, while entirely excluding Black and brown qaraites.

This class was a hybrid class (only meets 1x per week) so there is a decent amount of work / reading that you must do outside of class, but that's just what comes with a hybrid class. Prof. Goldish was incredibly knowledgeable regarding just about everything you could think of and as long as you read, you'll do just fine in the class.

I took his history of apocalypticism class and really enjoyed it. This class isn't for everyone. It was a 3 hr lecture with really heavy reading. I found professor goldish to be hilarious & extremely knowledgeable. This isn't an easy A but you learn a lot and it will change your perspective on a lot of different world issues. 10/10 would recommend.

Other than the fact that the class was a three hour lecture, I quite enjoyed my time in Professor Goldish's class. The man held my interest for more than half of each lecture, which was much more than I expected for a freshman history class that I was only taking to meet the requirement.

I am astounded every week at just how much this guy knows and loves to learn. He said last week he went several years reading Newton's manuscripts for 5 hours every day. He's written movies and books. Theres a lot of reading and the lectures get boring, but if you want to learn from an actual genius and a successful person, take a class with him.

Professor Goldish is one of those teachers who are way too smart to be spending their time teaching a GE. However, just listening to him talk is almost unbelievable considering his level of knowledge. He assigns an unreasonable amount of readings but if you pay attention in class you'll do fine on the quizzes-he summarizes the readings before quiz

Dr. Goldish is an inspiring instructor. He got me really excited about the history of science and the scientific revolution. I never thought that I would enjoy or learn so much from a history course. Make sure you do your papers in advance, and do some proper research and you can expect a good grade.
Loved him as a professor, very thorough and made mundane topics interesting. Lots of reading but it's a college history class so that should be expected.

God awful professor and class. He seems like a decent guy, but the entire class was structured in a way that promoted horrible scores.   Every day it was the same thing: read 50-100 pages of some dense book, listen to a nonsensical lecture where he mentions something that wasn't in the book, then take a 5 question pop quiz over lectures and books

I once came to college with the aspirations and excitement that i would be able to learn from amazing teachers who wanted nothing but for me to succeed. I want to happily inform you that this class has made me realize that my dreams are crushed and there are people out there who want to make you fail and hate your life.

It was the first time he taught this class on Witchcraft and Magic in Early Modern Europe, so I don't want to be critical. He seems like a nice guy, and if you're super into history then maybe he'd be interesting. However, if you're like me and just trying to get a GE credit done, his extensive tangents can get quite annoying.

I took this course thinking it would be different than it was. The whole course was based around the Salem Witch Trials, which I find completely uninteresting. Professor is a cool guy, but material was uninteresting.

I did not recieve the best grade in this class because I turned a paper in late but Professor Goldish might be my favorite teacher at OSU. He is original and interesting. I can't imagine someone knowing more about Jewish history that him.

His lectures were very good and he is an awesome prof, knows practically everything that is available to us right now as far as Jewish history in the renaissance. He grades very hard on the paper and the quizzes were simple as long as you studied the detailed lengthy readings. Not an easy class, hardest Ive taken, but good.
This class was really interesting, organized, and coordinated well.  There is a good amount of reading that you must do in order to get a good grade, but what do you expect, you're in college.
Great professor. A lot of reading, but that is a given. He was really interested in making his students better students and writers of history.
A ton of reading...but interesting lectures.  Quizzes fairly easy...1 big paper and a final. Very interesting man.
Great Prof!
Goldish is awesome - can make the most boring material interesting (or at least he'll try).  Demanding class - requires a lot on tests/papers but lenient when grading them.
HOW COULD I DO IT WITH OUT HIM. I LOVE THE EXTRACERICULAR ACTIVITIES
Funny, nice- has tendency to get lost on tangents, but makes the class fun. Lots of material to wade through, very approachable.
Best Professor I've ever had - very helpful and makes lecture very interesting.  Demands a lot but at the end his grading isn't too difficult.

I took Jewish Studies 201 with Dr. Goldish and it was wonderful.  His lectures are very entertaining, and as a teacher, he is very approachable.  He also does not interject his own opinion into the class.  Funny, engaging, and a fair grader.
No Comments

Great teacher! He never closed his door to me, even in the middle of lunch!  He encouraged me to apply to grad school and was very down to earth. Not a pompous academic. Don't miss his Salem Witches class!

Great teacher, makes use of a lot of comparisons with modern things which makes things easier to understand.  Funny, easy-going.  Always willing to offer extra help. Classes aren't cake, but definitely managable and interesting.

I've had several classes with Dr. Goldish.  He's funny and very helpful if you need it.  Really a nice person.  Be forewarned- TANGENT alert.  He does give study guides, and also grading criteria for papers, so all is not lost.

I loved taking history 286 with Dr Watkins. Yes I know I it says 460 above. It was a very entertaining class. If you don't like reading this class probably isn't right for you. our grade was determined by 3 papers and 2 mapping. In that even if you suck at Geography,,, like myself you will do fine. It's really easy.

This class was very free form - students picked a week and a topic to lead the 3 hour discussion on. You read a lot, but nothing crazy for a reading seminar. Her grading criteria is loose as well, in general participate a lot and you will only help your grade. 20 page final paper in addition to your discussion week also determine grade

The readings were the only good thing. The presentations are messy and barely put together (A whole week of lectures had no audio). Written midterm and final with no clear rubric or topic, just "write until you think you've written enough." Papers weren't that bad, but too much for a 2000 level class when paired with the written midterm and final.

Extremely condescending. Lectures were messy (filled with rants and barely put together Prezi slides). Doing too much for a second-session course- a 10 page paper is unnecessary in addition to a written midterm and final. Overall, it was a simple but disappointing class. Would never take this professor again.

A strict professor when it comes to deadlines. This is second session course, fast paced in my opinion. Make sure to complete your assignments ahead of time. I would advise you to take every single assignment seriously. The midterm is worth 15% and the final exam 20%. Both exams are essays. The 10-15 page final paper seems too much.

she does weekly reading discussions which are 20-200 pages long, also has a 10 page final due at the end of the class as well as the readings, a written mid term and final. I took history classes before but she expected too much in a session 2 course. Don't take if you're a stem major.
Overall seemed very disinterested in the course. Was difficult to reach when I had questions and was very unclear when it came to due dates with assignments not aligning with the syllabus.

Lots of reading every week. There's not many points throughout the semester, the biggest chunk of grades are towards the end so no matter how good you're doing, it could change easily. However, she is a lenient grader. The topics she asks you to write on are very specific.

She's okay but her grading criteria is very unclear and the entire class is just all around dry. There are four weeks left in the semester and I don't feel that I've learned anything. Take another GE if you have the option.

This professor expects way too much. The amount of work we have to do each week is insane. For example 3 hours of online lecture and 120 pages of reading. The reading were actual books, not textbooks, but it was challenging and took me and hour to read 35 pages. Idk how really expects her students to do 7 hours worth of work per week plus studying

Do not take her. Before this class I was passionate about learning American Indian history since I have taken classes on it before and loved it, after this class, it ruined my passion. Its unfortunate how a bad instructor can ruin something for you. She is condescending and unhelpful. Acts better than everyone. Many spelling errors, as well.

Does not care about her students. She was condescending. She put the wrong due dates on assignments and then does not take fault for it. Would not recommend this professor at all. She should not be working as a professor with her lack of professionalism. The work is not hard at all, she just does not assume responsibility for her faults.

I don't know about some of you graders but I have to laugh when someone had to read 40 pages per week and thought that was extremely difficult.  She picks out really good books and her lectures are well done.   So would take any of her courses again.  Better than most I have seen.

I have been at OSU for 3 years & this is the worst professor I've had.  She claims she is available for questions but when you take the time to reach out to her she is condescending and unhelpful.  I did more work for this class than my major (40 pages of reading per week) and struggled to get good grades.  Don't take this class, you'll regret it.

Insane amounts of reading and unclear guidelines for assignments. Grades seem entirely arbitrary, and if you ask her about what you did wrong in order to improve, she not only cannot give any good reason for her grading, but has such horrible grammar/writing skills that her responses  make no sense at all. Not sure how she got to OSU, but... avoid.

This professor has the most unrealistic expectations ever. Im an a  senior nursing  student and usually do well in classes and I'm not a stranger to a high work load but she expects so much reading its cry worthy. AVOID THIS CLASS. When you ask for help she puts little in addressing concerns. She's the most useless professor I've had.

I am in her online class, and she seems like a very good teacher; however, this class makes me do more work than my major classes combined. There is so much reading and work to do for just a GE class. Would not recommend.

This class was really interesting because she really made sure to teach the untold stories and causes behind the american revolution. There are 2 midterms and 1 paper,  but none were difficult if you came to class or met with your history study group to discuss beforehand (she makes the groups based on personality which was really cool).

Melissah is a great professor. You can tell she truly loves her job and it shows! However, I felt as though this class was taken too seriously for a GE. I worked very hard in this class, spent more time in here then classes related to my major (studied daily, started papers 2 weeks early) and still received grades lower than expected.

Melissah is a great professor that truly cares about the success of her students. She uses Prezi instead of powerpoint which can get cluttered, but she makes lectures interesting. You sign in to every lecture and can only miss one, but this is a huge grade booster. She always makes herself available to help and is very passionate. Would recommend!

Personally one of my favorite classes, I highly recommend taking it to meet the theme requirement. Dr. Harris's lectures were very interesting, and aside from the final project there is limited work outside the classroom. Classes are four times a week on west campus which is not very convenient, but the class was very intellectually stimulating.
If you are a strong reader and writer, Dr. Harris is a relatively easy professor to take a GE course from. A bit of a harsh grader for a 2000-level course.

The class was straightforward and easy. While lectures weren't always super engaging, they weren't bad by any means. If you understand repercussions of events and broad overview you will be fine for all of the assignments.  Not sure where some of the other PHR3708 reviews get their takes. It's a good GE with not a lot of work.

Dr. Harris has a difficult time articulating so lectures are boring and incohesive. For an elective course, Dr. Harris grades way too harshly on papers and exam short responses. You must EXCEED expectations just to get a decent grade. There are more interesting and easier classes to take than pharm/hist 3708. Would not recommend him or the class.

Dr.Harris is nice, but his grading irritated me. I kept missing 0.5-1 point until I finally learned that he takes off points if you follow the rubric exactly, you have to "exceed expectations" in order to receive full credit. I believe that if you follow the instructions you are given then you should get full credit. Responds to emails quickly!

- hard for no reason
- terrible at lecturing
- makes easy things 10 x harder 
- overall: 2/10

I LOVED Dr. Harris. He is extraordinarily kind and his lectures are clear and concise. He answers every email in a timely manner, grades consistently, and he is always available for clarification. Do not listen to anyone who has something bad to say about Dr. Harris because he is truly one of the kindest and best professors I've had here at OSU.

Dr. Harris is a nice guy with semi-interesting lectures, but his real downfall is his grading. He is extremely vague about his expectations for response papers, then rips into you in his feedback. Also quite a bit of reading homework every week.

If I had insomnia I would listen to one of Dr. Harris's lectures to sleep. He is very dry and not very dynamic. He's nice tho. There are no quizzes or exams so this class is not hard. His grading criteria is not very clear, so I hope he likes your writing. The grade is only made up of 2 papers and 2 projects. There is not a lot of room for error.

Professor Harris is a very sweet, very nice guy, he is always there to help you! I really liked this class a lot since I am was a science major, it was very interesting to learn all kinds of diseases. The only thing I didn't like about the class was the papers :/ I thought it was a fairly easy GE with a bunch of papers to write. we had a total of 3
Overall I am not a fan of Harris. lectures were heavy and not fun to go through and you get alot of reading with this guy. Reading that you will probably not do because it is very heavy

It's obvious that Dr. Harris is very passionate about history and public health and disease. There are only 3 papers and a final project at the end of the semester so it can be easy to get behind. He is a tough grader so its best not to wait until the last minute to write papers.
Dr. Harris is the hardest grader I've had at OSU. He doesn't give out rubrics but looks for extremely specific points in your papers. A lot of work each week.

Dr. Harris cares for his students success, but he definitely doesn't hand out A's. Going to his office hours goes a LONG way. I did learn a lot by taking his class, but there are definitely easier ways to get history credit than this class.

Dr. Harris is a very caring person and he puts a lot of effort into teaching this course. You can tell he really cares about the material and keeps lectures engaging. Readings can be very long and dense. He is a VERY tough grader! Overall very interesting course, not a lot of grades though so every grade matters.

Dr. Harris graded like this was a graduate class. He is a really nice guy, but the homework readings are usually around 20ish pages, and his quizzes are over the top difficult. On the exam, he was one of the hardest graders I have ever had at OSU. I think he tries really hard and loves to teach, but unnecessarily difficult

I took this class over the summer so there was a bit more work to do each week due to it not being a full semester. Some of his prompts were a bit challenging for a 2000-level course, but certainly still graded the papers as such. Would recommend this class especially over the summer if you need a GE.
Dr. Harris grades inconsistently without a rubric. His prompts are never clear and leave much room for guessing what he even wants. This was a shortened online class, and there was so much work.
Graded rough and gave papers every week of the summer online class I had him for.

The readings aren't necessarily required, but definitely read at least 50% of the required text. Harris lets you leave early for lecture sometimes. He is always willing to answer questions and further clarify information. Overall, a good teacher as he is very passionate about the History of Disease. Do a little over the minimum & you'll pass.

The class is interesting, the lectures are short and easy to follow, the reading, however, is really heavy and you do need to do all of it to answer the quizzes and discussion posts. The essays are the most difficult part (also most of your grade) and he is a tough grader.

A very boring class unless you enjoy history. He's passionate about water history, but you have to watch the lecture videos, read the required books, and any supplemental readings each week in order to do well on the quizzes. It's a lot of busy work for a history GE. Papers are the majority of your grade (60%) outside of quizzes and discussions.

Amazing professor! I took her online class and while it is a lot of reading and writing/typing for a 3 credit class, I appreciate how much effort she puts into grading and clearing up information. She gives so much extra credit, probably the most I've seen during my time at OSU. She genuinely wants you to pass and is generally flexible.

content and lectures were super interesting! as long as you turn in the assignments and cite your sources you'll be fine. the podcasts aren't really necessary to listen to + she uploads transcriptions for them. super understanding and she cut down the workload during busy times of the year. really enjoyed this course!

Lectures were really interesting and enjoyable. There is a good amount of reading, but that should be expected from an upper-level college history course. Lot of homework, reading journals and primary source reflections every week. 3 Primary Source Analysis papers (2-3 pages), 1 Modern Misuses paper (6-7 pages). Lot of work but overall great course

the podcasts are busy work (25 min- 1 hour), and 4-7 page papers every week. reading is about 75-100 pages per week. lectures are about a half hour each 2 or 3 each week. 3 primary source analysis papers, and 12 reading journals, there is extra credit but have to watch 5 hours of podcasts for only 5 points extra credit. nice professor otherwise.

Assigns a large amount of readings. Is lenient by dropping other assignments when big papers are due. Assigns big papers tri-weekly (4-7 pages). Some extra credit opportunities. A lot of typing for a 3 credit hour class.

Dr. Schoonover genuinely cares and is passionate about what she is teaching. Yes, there are a lot of readings and a good amount of writing assignments, but that is to be expected from an upper-level History course. That being said she is fair with grades and gives tons of feedback to help you improve and offers extra credit. She's awesome!

Professor Schoonover is the best instructor by far in the History Department. She is not only a great lecturer that engage with her students, but also is very passionate and wants her students to succeed. It is a guarantee that you will learn a vast amount of history and not be bored if you take one of her classes.

Overall u thought Dr. Smith was a really nice teacher and her class was very interesting. The course however is graded on a total of 4 papers, so each one counts. As long as you respond to her prompts clearly and have good evidence you will do well in the class.

I had taken her senior seminar class and was hoping that this class was going to be a bit easier but I was wrong, still a tough grader, the class was held early morning @9am and expected everyone to write a 4-page paper before class. Nice person but kinda obnoxious. there are 4 books, two of them are for the midterm and the final exams.

5 BOOKS, as a history major this was the most confusing class I have ever taken. You are told to know everything from the books, while the professor makes no sense whatsoever. the professor gives 4-page papers every week and expects a 15-page paper about a revolution at the end of the semester that you have no idea about.

Seminar of Latin American History class. 5 books, have to read one full book for one week. expects a 2 to 4-page summary of the book. Have to take it for a History B.A. requirement. VERY TOUGH GRADER, I had typed a good summary and was only given an 85% even though did everything that was mentioned. more writing than actually discussing the book.

Class is really frustrating and I'm a history major. Tough grader even on discussions where I have recited information straight from the lectures. You really have to work to get a good grade on assignments, and sometimes its not enough. Also so many papers. 2 small papers and 2 7 page papers. A lot harder than most 3000 level History courses.

5 wks in-- haven't gotten a single grade better than B no matter what I did. Grading delegated to assistants, assignments constantly marked as needing improvements, give no indication of how/what they want improved. Course online, so work load was worse and pre-recorded video lectures were joyless. Never want to take one of her classes again.

I think I would've enjoyed the class much more if the professor would have been able to be more clear on grading criteria. she never provided useful feedback on any of the papers that would indicate why a grade was lower than it should've been. readings and papers every week. she seems very knowledgeable but the lectures lacked passion

Dr. Smith was a nice lady but could be a better professor. She did not have very specific rubrics but expected you to be very specific. She is a very hard grader, giving me lower grades than I have ever gotten on papers and we had one all except for maybe 3 weeks out of the semester. She seemed afraid to give criticism but kept giving bad grades.

I took her History of Mexico class and found my self writing more in her class than in my writing class. Expect a LOT of writing with every week having a page worth of discussion, three film papers 2 pages long, and two essays 6-7 pages long. The class became a chore and I vowed never to take a class unless I know for sure what Im getting into.

Online lectures are basically a lot of lists. Does not care enough to make remotely clear pronunciations of VERY well known Latin American historical figures and makes many lofty claims about mexican history. Has "guides" and "grading criteria" but not really ever clear about these.

Professor Smith is great.  Funny and not intimidating at all!  She does expect the students to discuss a lot in class and will definitely call on you.  She's non-confrontational and will not correct anyone, even if they're wrong, which gets confusing.  My TA was tough and at times unfair.  Had way higher expectations than Professor Smith.
Never posts grades on Carmen, not clear about learning material

Professor Smith is a pretty good teacher overall. Class hit on some topics that were pretty boring to me even as a history major. She explains everything pretty well but her grading didnt really seem consistent,on a paper i though was one of my worst i got my best grade and some of my best efforts got me lower grades, but she is pretty good overall

I really enjoyed this class. Although Smith is not the best teacher I've ever had she is a good one. She cares a lot about the material and the lectures are never boring. I like to go class, which is great. The one downside is that she makes the students give group presentations which are usually pretty boring, but no big deal.

You could tell that Prof. Smith is very interested in womens roles and latin america, but she allowed her love of these subjects to interfere with her teaching of all around world history.  Her class was interesting but other far more important subjects could have been discussed.

Professor Smith is awesome!  Her lectures are extremely interesting and she's incredibly friendly.  Definitely, definitely sit at the front of the lecture hall; you'll get so much more out of it.  My only complaint is she is really, really obsessed with the Maya and you are forced to write a paper about them.  One of the best profs I've had at OSU.

Stephany was really cool but my TA was not. If you get Sarah Wegener try and find another TA. The TA's do all the grading, and Sarah was rude and unhelpful. I still got a B in the class, but would have rather had ANY of the other TA's. Sarah does not know what she's doing.

The class was easy, but I was hoping for more out of it. She concentrated too much on the history of women, while ignoring vital topics such as the development of Africa. She is clearly very passionate about her field and that was a plus. I think she relied too much on the TAs to answer questions. The tests are essay bassed so it is not that hard.
This class was very intersting but it was a lot of material. She was pretty cool. But not cool enough.

Professor Smith is awesome! She is so nice and funny, she makes class interesting.. Plus, she doesnt choose the boring topics to cover over the history of mexico, but rather focuses on the things that she knows will spark debate amongst her students... I recommend her to everyone! (and the history of mexico, its a great course)
not a very good teacher.  she reads from notes.  a high school student could do it.  and shes kinda annoying to listen to

Her history of Mexico class was terrible. She didn't go into depth at all, it was so basic. The class only met twice a week two hours each time and one hour was reserved for a movie (better then her teaching) and a second hour for watching a group project. Very easy but if you are actually interested in learning steer clear.

Kind of a ditz for a history professor, but she makes colorful powerpoint presentations and the history of Mexico is interesting as hell.  Smith did focus on women's issues a bit too much I thought.  Also an easy class, she tries to be "one of the students" before every class making small talks about parties on the weekend etc.

Good class, rather easy.  Kinda goofy teaching style, almost seems to 'dumb down' the material.  Felt that she got too specific when generalities were needed, it is the entire history of mexico, after all!!!  Interesting, cares about her students, varies up lectures with movies!

She was a pretty darn good teacher, and though she was a good lecturer, she mixed things up a bit with movies and so on, so it didn't get very stale. Taught to her strengths (Indian cultures in Central America), which worked out just fine.

Prof Smith is really fun and her lectures are interesting. I thought I'd hate having to take a history class for GEC, but this turned out to be my favorite class of the quarter and I'm even taking an upper level history class next quarter just to have Prof Smith again! Highly recommended!
She puts an outline of that days notes on the internet, makes lecture easier.  Shes very clear, movies are boring, but hey thats history.  I would recommend her.

Didn't buy the book, didn't go to lectures, got a B! Exams are typical HST style, you have a major paper assignment-not too bad. Films on fridays, with a short review due in rec. class.  Pretty easy, not demanding, slightly time consuming, but for the most part easy and I'd take her again.
Great guy great teacher!

I dont know about the other reviews where he was a TA, but I took Kevins online 4 week class for HIST 1151 and it was the easiest thing ever. Daily lecture, but I listened to it on double speed. Three small books. Whole grade was based on proving you watched/read. Easiest A ever.

Im glad this guy finally got a rate my prof. If I had known he was the grader for this class I wouldve avoided it. He cannot wrap his head around the fact that his class is a GE, not a 5000 level course. Due to essays making up the entire grade, he has screwed over so many people. Do not take classes with him ever!

Kevin is the TA, and grades some essays. In all honesty, he seems like a nice guy from what he says in class. However, for a GE course, his grading is terrible. There is a huge difference in grades from people whose papers are graded by the Professor, and those whose papers are graded by Kevin. He has unreasonably high expectations. Avoid!!!

Environmental and business history is his bread and butter and it shows. Lectures and readings were amazing and left me thinking about American history in ways I hadn't before. He's super caring about students. Most of the time his slides are very sparse on words so you do have to zone in a bit, but he also posts lectures. 10/10 highly recommend.
worst professor in main campus

Nice professor with interesting lectures. The class is more business/environmental than history, so keep that in mind. Very few grades + I found him to be a tough grader--so make sure to turn in the weekly reflections. He also vaguely resembles Jonah Ryan from VEEP, so that may be disconcerting. If you care about the environment, you'll enjoy!

You need to attend/read/take notes to synthesize lessons so that you can do well on your evaluated work (essays). But he's great at teaching, is very available, and gives amazing feedback. Your thinking and writing skills WILL improve, and you'll be excited to engage. If you're bored in his class, you're wasting a seat. Jaw-dropping lectures.

I can't recommend Professor Elmore enough as he not only has amazing and interesting lectures but is also an expert in his field and does his best to share the information that he knows with you. As far as assignments there are a few essays and an op-ed, however they are fairly easy and Bart is happy to help. I can't recommend this course enough!

Genuinely caring and great guy. However, it felt more like an environmental history course more so than a political history course at quite a few times. But again, super caring and will round your grade up I honestly feel like if I was in one of his environmental history courses I would have loved it more.

Took bart for a gened and ending loving him and gaining a real intresting in the subject. There is a ton to read but you can get by by skiming and marking important details. Go to his office hours before you submit the project-huge help

Bart is easily the best professor I've had at OSU. Super into improv reenactments of various historical events (somehow not as cheesy as it sounds). My only regret is not taking more classes with him.

Professor Elmore is the best professor I've had at OSU! His lectures are incredibly engaging and thought-provoking; you will not find yourself bored in class! He approaches the field of History with mindfulness and compassion which allows his students to broaden their perspectives and truly gain a deeper understanding of the lessons being taught.

Professor Elmore is definitely one of the best professors on campus. The structure of the class is clear-cut and not difficult whatsoever if you just show up to class and complete the work. All the lectures are interesting and force you to think outside the box. He really just wants you to succeed and learn in his class.

Excellent lecturer. Closest thing to a rock star on campus, but doesn't act like one. Cares about students. Does not post lecture slides. Weekly readings are very interesting. Midterm and Final were graded tough by the TA. Term paper is a bit confusing. Overall excellent professor.

Bart was possibly the best lecturer I've ever had, but the class is only graded on a few papers, which is kinda annoying but it is a writing course. The graders were somewhat harsh, but the papers weren't long and I could write them in a day. Attendance wasn't mandatory but I he still kept me engaged in class and I always went. Rounded 89.5 to A-.

You can tell he is passionate about his job through lectures. There are reading reflections for participation (2x per week) and 3 essays. He and TA were very understanding and gave extensions when asked because I felt overwhelmed with essays. Very few assignments though, so give your best writing effort. Not the best writer and I got an A still.

This professor is great and a good guy, but really do not take this class if you are not a strong writer. I'm not sure why this class was recommend to me when I'm a business major who just needed a history credit, but the grading is harsh. There's also only like 5 assignments (all papers) and I did bad on one and could never get my grade back up.

Professor Elmore may have been one of my favorite professors I ever had at OSU and I was not a history major. His lectures were so interesting and definitely worth going to. As a professor he is very accessible and easy to approach. If you put in the work for this class, you will do well. Professor Elmore sets his students up for success.
No doubts, just take the class with him and you'll be in good hands

This class discussed how big business affects the environment and society in general, and was absolutely fascinating! Professor Elmore is an incredibly interesting person and clearly has so much knowledge on the topic. He also makes lectures fun by playing music and having us watch documentaries relevant to the readings! Very valuable material

My favorite. He genuinely cares about his students and is so passionate about the subject material. It's great to have a prof that believes in you. He makes lectures engaging and I looked forward to class every week. There is a lot of reading and your grade is made up of 4 papers and written reflections, but all the material is interesting.
Literally one of the most understanding Prof ever, he cares really and is beyond amazing. My only regret I wish I could take more classes with him. Btw he cares about the environment:)

Amazing class with an amazing professor. The course content is incredible and very important to know for the future. Major grades are a midterm, final, two drafts of a 7-8 page research paper, and participation (which is a 250 word reflection on each of the assigned readings). Dr. Elmore is caring, and I would happily take one of his course again!

Professor Elmore is a king. He truly cares about the environment and environmental history. His class was one of my favorites in college and it was consistently interesting and engaging, I learned so many new things. My only regret is I didn't take it earlier so I could take more of his classes. Definitely take a class from Prof Elmore!

if you have the chance, take a class with bart. his lectures are amazing and he's an interesting guy. for his office hours he likes to take students to lunch and he's interested in getting to know us. i've never felt like a professor has cared about me and my individual success before i took his class. grading criteria could be more clear though.

Greatest professor I've had at OSU thus far. Genuinely cares about the wellbeing of his students and loves hearing about everyone's collective knowledge on topics. He always tells his students how excited he is to be in class. An incredibly knowledgable professor who loves what he teaches and that shows in every lecture I've ever attended of his.

One of my favorite classes I have taken. The lectures were amazing and the class was very thought-provoking. The exams were fair, and he made it very clear what was expected for them. He always presented the material in a very interesting and energetic way. Extremely caring and helpful. I would highly recommend his class.

He is an absolutely amazing professor and lecturer and was genuinely sad when the class ended. You have to read a chapter in a book before every class and submit short reflection. Attendance is also mandatory. The major grades are two 5-7 page research papers, one midterm, And one final. Do the work and it is a pretty easy A.

The History of American Capitalism was awesome, made the course really interesting. However, we had to write two 7 page essays on the environmental history of a company. If you do not want that commitment, I would not take the class. Otherwise, I loved the course.
This guy is awesome. I hate history but he does such a great job I actually paid attention.

Best lecturer I've ever had, hands down. Prof Elmore is inspiring, entertaining, and overall a great guy. He structures the class in a way that makes sense, and challenges you just enough to keep you engaged but never overwhelmed. I would recommend him to absolutely anyone, regardless of your interest in history. Wish he taught all my classes!

Professor Elmore is by far my favorite professor I've had at Ohio State. His lectures were incredibly engaging and I looked forward to going to his class. TAs were encouraging and helpful and graded pretty straightforward. I've recommended this class to all my friends!
Really engaging lectures. Has a mandatory reading every class for participation, but it's definitely manageable to get an A.

Cool professor but he assigns small writing assignments for each reading -_- . Environmental history is superrr boring but he made it sorta interesting. Oh yeah only we were permitted only one unexcused absence...

This class made me love history, which I have never enjoyed. Mr. Elmore is an incredible lecturer and I recommended this class to all my friends. The recitation is a little boring but I was actually excited to go to lecture which is weird.

Professor Elmore is the best instructor I've ever had. He truly cares about his students and the lectures are amazing. You can tell he knows and is passionate about what he is teaching. Recitation is a bit pointless but manageable. Take his class if you have the chance!!

Professor Elmore is awesome. I am not a history person, but he really makes his lectures interesting. He is great at keeping the students engaged. If you go to lecture and recitation, you will do great in his class.

Professor Elmore is my favourite professor. Its my earliest class and I actually love waking up to go to his lectures. You can tell he really loves what he teaches. Attendance is mandatory. Dont need the book. Readings during the week and a question sent to TAs before recitation. 3 major papers, a midterm and a final. 11/10 recommend this class.

Awesome lectures. I can't fall asleep, even if I try. I have learnt quite a bit from his cool personal experience stories too. He's very amicable and helpful. So are his TAs. Tests and assignments are few, but hard, long and harshly graded. Give time to learning modern US history and it's an A.
He loves what he is teaching and he will make you love it too. Various readings are due with a synopsis of the reading the night before class.
One of the greatest educators I've ever had. Prof. Elmore structured his course in a way that made sense. Honestly a genuine and kind person which makes learning from him easy.

Dr. Butler is an absolute gem. She is so passionate and gives amazing lectures that make class so enjoyable. She also really loves getting to know her students personally. She definitely can be a harsh grader though and blunt with feedback. However, it's not for the sake of being mean but because she wants to help show where you can grow.

Professor Butler is by far one of the best professors at Ohio State! She is funny and kind, and her passion is contagious. During the term, there were two 6-page papers and weekly/bi-weekly "reading responses," usually a page or two. The final was the roughest part, as it was a paper essay written in class, but she gave you time to prepare.

I had so much fun taking this class! Dr. Butler gives passionate lectures, which make the class super engaging. The workload is manageable outside of class with weekly discussion posts, a 6-page paper, and a final research paper. Dr. Butler wants all of her students to succeed and will give you plenty of resources if you ask for them!

One of the absolute best professors I have had here at OSU. She cares so deeply about her students and about her courses. She is not nearly as hard of a grader as other reviews say. Go to office hours and work hard on your papers and you will be rewarded. Read every comment and don't take it personally-- she wants you to succeed!

very nice professor but abnormally hard grader, especially on papers. i have gone my entire academic career being praised for my writing abilities (even amongst the history department) but i received my first B on a paper in this course.

very passionate and enjoyable professor, just be aware.

She gives a lot of reading, but is honest about not expecting anyone to fully understand it- its written a LONG time ago. Tough grader, but fair, and gives a lot of feedback that has helped me. It IS a history course... you have to expect some intense reading, but you get used to it.

The worst thing about this class is probably how you normally read 30-60 pages per week. Once you get used to that, it isn't bad at all though. She's really passionate about the class and in my class, there was always passionate discussion between her and the students. You learn some interesting stuff, fun class.

Dr. Butler is clearly very passionate about her area of expertise. Her lectures are enthusiastic and fun. However, she grades papers harder than any professor I've had before, and I'm an English major, so writing successful papers is a breeze for me. I'd never gotten below a B on a paper until this class. There was no meeting her expectations.

Insanely strict attendance policy. 60-70 pages of reading per class with a writing assignment due before the beginning of class. Completely out of touch and does not care that a pandemic may cause your priorities to shift away from a GE history course. Dont waste your time and find a better class with a more understanding professor.

If you are not willing to devote your entire life to her class, do not take her. She assigns a ridiculous amount of writing assignments, brutally grades your papers, and takes it as a personal offense if you are not obsessed with her material. She would fare much better at a liberal arts school. You cannot expect a class of 100+ to become bffs.

Writing assignment due EVERY class. Tons of tedious readings that are written in old fashion english (like Shakespeare). You can only miss about 3 classes, after that u lose a full letter grade. I did practically all the work & got still got a D because I missed too many lectures. Exams are a big writing assignment, so grading is partly subjectiv

She is the most amazing lecturer and really nice, but she grade ridiculously hard for the most part even when compared to the rest of the department. You will definitely learn a lot and enjoy yourself... until your final grade comes in.

Dr. Butler is definitely a tough grader. However, she's really knowledgeable and interested in what she teaches and is enthusiastic. Her lectures were mostly discussion and little notes, which was a little boring and we had to read 40-60 total pages a week, but the homework was not difficult, and I enjoyed learning about medieval crime and law.

I cannot say enough great things about Dr. Butler. Take a class with her even if you have little interest or background in medieval history because she is a fabulous lecturer who makes any material interesting and relevant. This class was fairly reading heavy and covered thematic topics as opposed to chronological events.

I HATE history, but I loved Dr. Butlers class. Very good GE for non-history majors as she is one of the few that understands the non-history majors are only here for a GE requirement. Super funny and it's a really interesting class!

Dr. Butler is one of the most caring, enthusiastic, passionate teachers at this university. You have to read a boatload of stories and books: 40 or so pages before each lecture. However, they're interesting. There are 3 papers and a final; the grading is pretty tough on those so you HAVE to keep up on the readings in order to achieve success!

As a person and a teacher Dr. Butler is awesome. I had to work my butt off to get an A though. I've always gotten A's on English papers, but the papers in this class are graded harsher than any honors English class I have taken. The history of witchcraft was interesting, but an insane amount of reading & few grades. Go to all extra credit events!

Dr. Butler is wonderful. Her class discussions were in depth and clear in knowledge you needed to know for essays and exams, but there was also plenty of time to dig into topics the class was most interested in. Medieval Women's course definitely required work, but it was so fun it barely felt like it!

Dr. Butler is by far one of my favorite professors I've had at OSU. She's so intelligent and witty and her historical knowledge is evident in her sense of humor. The readings and participation are necessary for doing well, and she is a tough grader, but you will get so much out of the class that it's all worth it. 100% recommend any class with her.

This was a fascinating class and she was always willing to help or talk. The reading is pretty mandatory but it's not that hard of a class, just participate! I appreciated the structure of the class, it really helped me learn the material.

This was my favorite class of the semester by far!  Dr. Butler's class was always fun and the topics were interesting!  The class was rarely boring, and was always lively with discussion.  I can't wait to take another one of her classes in the fall!
Really awesome class and knowledgeable professor!

Sara Butler is an amazing teacher. Yes, she can be a little difficult when it comes to grading papers, but that is offset by a bunch of extra points that she floats your way through participation and reading responses. Dr. Butler is knowledgeable, accessible, kind, and most of all: enthusiastic!! I would highly recommend taking her class!

The course was really interesting and I feel like I got a lot out of it, despite it being just a GE for me. She gave a lot of feedback and was always available to talk about anything that I needed help on. I would definitely recommend to anyone who wants to learn cool stuff about the Middle Ages. I plan on taking courses with Butler in the future.

She's honestly amazing. Great history teacher, even better person. She has reading responses due for each class but they honestly are not bad at all. Super interesting class! I want to take more of her classes in the future.

Sara is a great lecturer. The class was not super tough, the assignments were graded harshly. For a person with minimal prior knowledge I learned tons & worked hard but it was not reflected in my final grade. All in all do not take her class if you are looking to put in a reasonable effort & get a decent grade.

In many respects Butler is a great teacher, gun-ho, fun, entertaining. On the other hand she's a very hard grader, hard to know what she really wants on her papers, and can be a bit ruthless in those regards. Lots of reading and writing summaries over it. On one hand she's very good, on the other...

Prof Butler is a great, funny lecturer. Takes attendance every class. 2 papers and 2 midterms, plus reading responses to primary sources every class. She gives a study guide for midterms that were pretty easy. TA's grade the papers mostly.  I had some previous knowledge which helped. Overall not a difficult class with interesting subject material

Class was very simple and easy. Professor seemed nice and excited about teaching. The only assignments were the weekly discussion posts, midterm, and final. Lectures were insightful but very long. He also offers lots of extra credit!
The easiest class I've taken at OSU. He is generous, forgivable. Not many homework. One 3 pages essay and final essay. Take this during summer tho.
They're a little late with grading, but if you use the feedback given you will do great. There's also 2 chances for extra credit.

Professor Cahn is a great professor, he clearly loves history and loves teaching it. The class was entirely online, you can only fail if you don't try at all. Read the powerpoints and watch the lectures, post discussions on time, and if you're not bad at writing papers you'll be fine.

This class was entirely online, and honestly if all the content was published in at once you could probably get it done in one day. Super easy, yet super interesting. Theres extremely clear (and lenient) grading criteria, so I think the only way to fail is if you don't try at all.
Great professor, and very helpful if you contact him. 100% recommend.
Pretty clear expectations and organization. Was a very interesting guy and knew more than I would imagine anyone would know about the history and intricacies of food.

lectures are 1.5 hours long, don't watch them, read the slides and do the discussion post. You will get an A. I did this course in the 8-week format, and I could have done the whole course in at least 2 weeks.
Didn't watch a single lecture or read a single text he assigned and I still got an A lmao. Super easy class; I cannot recommend it more. He only assigns two papers and weekly discussion posts.

Easiest class I've ever taken (history of tech). I honestly only skimmed the lectures/slides and just was sure to get all of the discussion posts and essays done. The majority of the grade is based on the two essays (three if you do EC) so I guess make sure you're decent at writing going into this. Cahn is great, entertaining and informative

Even the short, half semester version of this class is manageable, and made me wish I had taken the longer version since we had to miss a few lectures due to time. Prof was super nice and had really interesting lectures. The final was worth 40% of the grade. Only thing is he uses graders so feedback was really limited and check that grades match.

My favorite class this semester. Watch the lectures, do the weekly discussion post, and work on the essays ahead of time. The lectures were interesting, essays were easy, and the final project was stress-free and fun. Dr. Cahn was also extremely friendly over email and really cared about my concerns. Take this course, and you will have a good time.

This class was incredibly easy with 1 discussion per week + 2 replies, and 3 essays. Although I never once interacted with him since I was online, he seems like a really nice guy who cares a lot about the class. Other than that, I really enjoyed learning in his class although it was a GEN ED theme requirement, I would highly rec this class! :)

This professor was great. I had him for an asynchronous, second session class so I did not get to see much of him but I loved what I did. The class is super easy and fair with weekly discussion posts and two essays which are both easy. He cares about what he's teaching and super understanding of students. 10/10, would recommend.
Very manageable even as a half-semester course. Instructor is extremely kind and understanding. Online lectures are long but valuable.

This professor is super helpful and overall really nice. This class has been easy I would say, but I've also learned a lot. As long as you read through the slides/ or watch them, discussions and essays are fairly easy to do. This work load is only a discussion a week and a couple essays, so I'm really glad I took this class to fill a GE.
